<item>
            <title>[LANG-104] NestableException API DOC not accurate</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-104</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Context :&lt;br/&gt;
I use a sub class of NestableException which needs to be serializable because &lt;br/&gt;
thrown in a session EJB.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Problem :&lt;br/&gt;
Each time i throw my exception i get &lt;br/&gt;
a &quot;org.apache.commons.lang.exception.NestableException is not serializable&quot; &lt;br/&gt;
exception.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Bug :&lt;br/&gt;
When I look at the following API documentation &lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/lang/api/org/apache/commons/lang/exception/Ne&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/lang/api/org/apache/commons/lang/exception/Ne&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
stableException.html i see that NestableException implements Serializable but &lt;br/&gt;
when I look at the code in the commons-lang-src-20030813.zip archive I see &lt;br/&gt;
that NestableException declaration is only&lt;br/&gt;
&quot;public class NestableException extends Exception implements Nestable&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows XP&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340905">LANG-104</key>
            <summary>NestableException API DOC not accurate</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="5">Cannot Reproduce</resolution>

                            <comment id="12404861" author="bayard" created="Fri, 15 Aug 2003 07:42:25 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Going back to at least JDK 1.2.2, java.lang.Throwable implemented Serializable. Anyone &lt;br/&gt;
with ideas on what could be going wrong here?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I thought maybe that Nestable was declaring itself to be Serializable at one point, but &lt;br/&gt;
looking at the CVS history it never has been such. The only class in the lang.exception &lt;br/&gt;
package to mess with Serializable has been NestableDelegate.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404862" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Fri, 15 Aug 2003 08:37:38 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;FWIW, Sun&apos;s Java 1.1.8 defines Throwable as:&lt;br/&gt;
public class Throwable extends Object implements Serializable &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404863" author="phil@steitz.com" created="Fri, 15 Aug 2003 13:44:54 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Looks to me like serialization of NestableException is tested in&lt;br/&gt;
NestableExceptionTestCase.testSerialization()&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It would help to see some sample code showing the failure.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404864" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sat, 29 Nov 2003 23:08:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Closing as WORKSFORME (unreproducable)&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-102] [lang] Refactor Entities methods</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-102</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The pairs of escape and unescape methods in Entities need to be modified so that&lt;br/&gt;
they call each other (one escape to the other escape etc). Otherwise there&apos;s a&lt;br/&gt;
large chunk of repeated code that gives us a high chance of errors.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12343042">LANG-102</key>
            <summary>[lang] Refactor Entities methods</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="bayard">Henri Yandell</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 24 Apr 2006 13:19:35 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 6 Feb 2007 23:47:14 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Mon, 1 Jan 2007 23:29:28 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.2</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.3</fixVersion>

                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12454689" author="tblachowicz" created="Thu, 30 Nov 2006 16:15:50 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Patch for class org.apache.commons.lang.Entities (src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/Entities.java)&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12454690" author="tblachowicz" created="Thu, 30 Nov 2006 16:21:17 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I have one comment regarding the patch I&apos;ve contibuted.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;There is a minor issue with IOException that could be thown by Entities.*escape(Writer, String) methods. Methods Entities.*escape(String) don&apos;t declare IOException so I decided to catch it and wrap within bare RuntimeException. Although the exception can&apos;t occur since I pass java.io.StringWriter instance into Entities.*escape(Writer, String) methods.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If you don&apos;t like this approach pleas let me know.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12454784" author="tblachowicz" created="Fri, 1 Dec 2006 00:13:38 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Patch for class org.apache.commons.lang.Entities (src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/Entities.java)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;/ignore previously submitted patch, it&apos;s a wrong file/&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12461655" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Mon, 1 Jan 2007 23:25:55 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Refactored escape and unescape methods to remove code duplication.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12461656" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Mon, 1 Jan 2007 23:27:49 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;FWIW, I could not use the attached patch files. They appear to be too old to match against what was in SVN. So I refactored from scratch, no biggie.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12461657" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Mon, 1 Jan 2007 23:29:28 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;committed.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

                            <comment id="12405156" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Wed, 24 Sep 2003 04:00:04 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;It requires test cases, and better methods that allow the format to be &lt;br/&gt;

                            <comment id="12405157" author="n.metchev@teamphone.com" created="Wed, 24 Sep 2003 15:32:39 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;making it public shouldn&apos;t require test cases and any other functionality than &lt;br/&gt;

people will use it. As it is now it shouldn&apos;t even be shipped with the jar.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405158" author="bayard" created="Sun, 27 Jun 2004 11:11:20 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Having high test coverage is an important target for Lang, so things do not get&lt;br/&gt;

dupe of #15082.&lt;/p&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-100] [lang] RandomStringUtils.random() family of methods create invalid unicode sequences</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-100</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Problem are surrogate pairs: &lt;br/&gt;
E.g. RandomStringUtils.random(int) may create strings with a high surrogate not&lt;br/&gt;
followed by a low surrogate character.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;When processing them, we get errors in string-conversion-functions later on.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342756">LANG-100</key>
            <summary>[lang] RandomStringUtils.random() family of methods create invalid unicode sequences</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="stefanhoehne@fastmail.fm">Stefan H&#246;hne</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 29 Nov 2005 21:57:38 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 6 Feb 2007 23:47:14 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 27 Jun 2006 07:28:09 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.1</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.2</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12410969" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Thu, 1 Dec 2005 13:19:10 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Can you please provide a unit test case patch to demonstrate the issue? Thanks,&lt;br/&gt;
Gary.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12410970" author="stefanhoehne@fastmail.fm" created="Tue, 6 Dec 2005 05:35:21 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Sorry, have never added a unit test patch. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Here is a junit test case showing the problem. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;	/**&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Creates a human readable representation of any unicode character.&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@param c - a unicode character&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@return human readable representation for c&lt;br/&gt;
	 */&lt;br/&gt;
	static public String makeStringFromChar(char c)
	{
		// dirty for getting the char code from a character
		return Integer.toHexString((new Character(c)).hashCode());
	}&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;	/**&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Checks if the string got by 
{@link RandomStringUtils#random(int)}&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;can be converted to UTF-8 and back without loss.&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@author stefanhoehne@fastmail.fm&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@throws Exception&lt;br/&gt;
	 */&lt;br/&gt;
	public void testRandom() throws Exception&lt;br/&gt;
	{&lt;br/&gt;
		final int size = 5000;&lt;br/&gt;
		final String encoding = &quot;UTF-8&quot;;&lt;br/&gt;
		final String orig = RandomStringUtils.random(size);&lt;br/&gt;
		final byte[] bytes = orig.getBytes(encoding);&lt;br/&gt;
		final String copy = new String(bytes, encoding);&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;		// for a verbose compare:&lt;br/&gt;
		for (int i=0; i&amp;lt;orig.length() &amp;amp;&amp;amp; i&amp;lt;copy.length(); ++i)&lt;/p&gt;
		{
			char o = orig.charAt(i);
			char c = copy.charAt(i);
			assertEquals(&quot;differs at &quot; + i + &quot;(&quot; + makeStringFromChar(o) + &quot;,&quot; +
makeStringFromChar(c) + &quot;)&quot;, o, c);
		}
&lt;p&gt;		// compare length also&lt;br/&gt;
		assertEquals(orig.length(), copy.length());&lt;br/&gt;
		// just to be complete&lt;br/&gt;
		assertEquals(orig, copy);&lt;br/&gt;
	}&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12410971" author="bayard" created="Mon, 24 Apr 2006 13:45:22 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Test indeed fails. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Codewise, the a start of 0 and an end of Integer.MAX_VALUE are used. Each time&lt;br/&gt;
around the loop a random number is created and the following test is applied:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;            if ((letters &amp;amp;&amp;amp; Character.isLetter(ch))&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;div class=&apos;table-wrap&apos;&gt;
&lt;table class=&apos;confluenceTable&apos;&gt;&lt;tbody&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;th class=&apos;confluenceTh&apos;&gt; (numbers &amp;amp;&amp;amp; Character.isDigit(ch))&lt;/th&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;th class=&apos;confluenceTh&apos;&gt; (!letters &amp;amp;&amp;amp; !numbers)) {&lt;/th&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;/tbody&gt;&lt;/table&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;


&lt;p&gt;In this case, letters and numbers are false, so it passes quite happily (as it&apos;s&lt;br/&gt;
not a random restricted to letters or digits). &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So we need to be adding another test here, whether the character is correct&lt;br/&gt;
unicode for the high/low surrogate bit. Googling, it looks like high surrogates&lt;br/&gt;
are on the range 55296 (D800) to 56191 (DB7F); and there are &apos;private use high&lt;br/&gt;
surrogates&apos; from 56192 (DB80) to 56319 (DBFF). So if a random character exists&lt;br/&gt;
within that range, the following character must be a low surrogate. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Low surrogates are 56320 (DC00) to 57343 (DFFF). &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;So, dumb pseudo-code:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;if(char &amp;gt; 55296 &amp;amp;&amp;amp; char &amp;lt; 56191)&lt;br/&gt;
    count--&lt;br/&gt;
    char&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;count&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; = 56320 + random(128)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;But I don&apos;t get what the private high surrogates are, I can&apos;t find the &apos;low&apos;&lt;br/&gt;
alternative (not that I understand much of this). Was looking at this site: &lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.alanwood.net/unicode/private_use_high_surrogates.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.alanwood.net/unicode/private_use_high_surrogates.html&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Any thoughts?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12417930" author="bayard" created="Tue, 27 Jun 2006 07:28:09 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fixed for high/low I believe, but private high get skipped currently.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;svn ci -m &quot;Adding a test and a fix for &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-100&quot; title=&quot;[lang] RandomStringUtils.random() family of methods create invalid unicode sequences&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-100&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-100&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt;. This is a bug in which the randomly created String can some&lt;br/&gt;
times be illegal unicode; because the code does not consider when relationships exist between characters. High and low surrogates are now dealt with, but I&apos;m skipping private high surrogates because I can&apos;t find out what to do. Need to go plod very slowly through the spec. This site was very useful: &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.alanwood.net/unicode/private_use_high_surrogates.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://www.alanwood.net/unicode/private_use_high_surrogates.html&lt;/a&gt;&quot; src/&lt;b&gt;/org/apache/commons/lang/Random&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Sending        src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/RandomStringUtils.java&lt;br/&gt;
Sending        src/test/org/apache/commons/lang/RandomStringUtilsTest.java&lt;br/&gt;
Transmitting file data ..&lt;br/&gt;
Committed revision 417319.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-99] new StringUtils.replaceChars behaves differently from old CharSetUtils.translate</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-99</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The CharSetUtils.translate(String str, String searchChars, String replaceChars) &lt;br/&gt;
method from Lang 1.0.1 is marked deprecated, pointing me at &lt;br/&gt;
StringUtils.replaceChars(String str, String searchChars, String replaceChars) &lt;br/&gt;
from Lang 2.0. The routines are coded quite differently, and in fact yield &lt;br/&gt;
different outputs at times. StringUtils.replaceChars() does not translate some &lt;br/&gt;
strings properly.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;String original=&quot;abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyzABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ123456789&quot;;&lt;br/&gt;
String trans=&quot;nopqrstuvwxyzabcdefghijklmNOPQRSTUVWXYZABCDEFGHIJKLM567891234&quot;;&lt;br/&gt;
System.out.println(CharSetUtils.translate(&quot;d216.102oren&quot;, original, trans));&lt;br/&gt;
System.out.println(StringUtils.replaceChars(&quot;d216.102oren&quot;, original, trans));&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Running this fragment gets me this:&lt;br/&gt;
q651.506bera&lt;br/&gt;
d141.401beea&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The first one is correct.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341147">LANG-99</key>
            <summary>new StringUtils.replaceChars behaves differently from old CharSetUtils.translate</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="loren@siebert.org">Loren Siebert</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 12 Dec 2003 03:15:19 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 16 Dec 2009 08:50:31 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 16 Dec 2009 08:50:31 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.1</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12405626" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Fri, 12 Dec 2003 06:23:30 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Well, this is a tricky one. I feel the basic problem is that the Javadoc&lt;br/&gt;
underspecifies the behavior of both methods, so perhaps we could discuss first&lt;br/&gt;
what the behavior /should be/. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The heart of the problem is that the CharSetUtils method is a one pass map-style&lt;br/&gt;
of method, while the StringUtils method is not, it uses a nested loop, which is&lt;br/&gt;
somewhat contradictory to the Javadoc comment of doing the work &quot;in one go&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405627" author="loren@siebert.org" created="Fri, 12 Dec 2003 07:17:20 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This sort of translate functionality exists in other languages, too. Perl and &lt;br/&gt;
PHP both have them, and they work the way that translate() worked in 1.0.1. &lt;br/&gt;
Regardless of what the new replaceChars() method is trying to do, it would be &lt;br/&gt;
nice to have something backwards compatible with translate() that shares common &lt;br/&gt;
behavior with similar methods in other languages.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405628" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Thu, 11 Mar 2004 07:56:22 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;CVS implementation now works for the supplied test case.&lt;br/&gt;
ReplaceChars() differs from Translate() in the deletion behaviour when &lt;br/&gt;
replaceChars is shorter than searchChars. This is documented in CharSetUtils.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405629" author="bayard" created="Wed, 26 Apr 2006 13:10:55 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;2.1 released, closing.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-98] [lang] DurationFormatUtils.formatDurationWords() incorrectly formats values ending in 1 but greater than 1</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-98</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Currently, values ending in 1 but greater than 1 (41, for example) return a&lt;br/&gt;
non-plural response (second, hour, day, etc). The culprit code appears to be at&lt;br/&gt;
the end of the method:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;// handle plurals&lt;br/&gt;
duration = StringUtils.replaceOnce(duration, &quot;1 seconds&quot;, &quot;1 second&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
duration = StringUtils.replaceOnce(duration, &quot;1 minutes&quot;, &quot;1 minute&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
duration = StringUtils.replaceOnce(duration, &quot;1 hours&quot;, &quot;1 hour&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
duration = StringUtils.replaceOnce(duration, &quot;1 days&quot;, &quot;1 day&quot;);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;One approach to fix this might be to use a regular expression to replace only if&lt;br/&gt;
 1 appears as a single digit rather than with another digit. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m thinking of something like: (duration.replaceFirst(&quot;(&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;^\\d&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;)(&lt;br class=&quot;atl-forced-newline&quot; /&gt;d) seconds&quot;,&lt;br/&gt;
&quot;$1$2 second&quot;)&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Linux&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342534">LANG-98</key>
            <summary>[lang] DurationFormatUtils.formatDurationWords() incorrectly formats values ending in 1 but greater than 1</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="3">Duplicate</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="asf.robmoore@xoxy.net">Rob Moore</reporter>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-95] [lang] StringUtils.defaultString: Documentation error</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-95</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;There is an error in the JavaDoc description of the second version of &lt;br/&gt;
StringUtils.defaultString.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The current version is:&lt;br/&gt;
defaultString(String str, String defaultStr)&lt;br/&gt;
Returns either the passed in String, or if the String is null, an empty String &lt;br/&gt;
(&quot;&quot;).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The correct version should be, e.g.:&lt;br/&gt;
Returns either the passed in String, or if the String is null, the value of &lt;br/&gt;
&amp;lt;code&amp;gt;defaultStr&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt;.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341409">LANG-95</key>
            <summary>[lang] StringUtils.defaultString: Documentation error</summary>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-94] [lang] NumberUtils.isNumber allows illegal trailing characters</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-94</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;This bug report is based on a post to commons-dev from Eric Pugh.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I am attaching a patch that includes the test case that Eric posted and two&lt;br/&gt;
others that confirm that the current code will accept strings with trailing&lt;br/&gt;
characters that are not type qualifiers.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The patch also adds a check to NumberUtils.isNumber() that causes these strings&lt;br/&gt;
to be rejected. Assuming that my understanding of the code is correct, this&lt;br/&gt;
patch should fix the problem without changing behavior on other strings. All&lt;br/&gt;
other tests succeed with the patch applied.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340764">LANG-94</key>
            <summary>[lang] NumberUtils.isNumber allows illegal trailing characters</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="phil@steitz.com">Phil Steitz</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 6 Jun 2003 11:14:32 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:39:12 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:39:12 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.0</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12404406" author="phil@steitz.com" created="Fri, 6 Jun 2003 11:15:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=6665)&lt;br/&gt;
patches to NumberUtils, NumberUtilsTest&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404407" author="dep4b" created="Fri, 6 Jun 2003 11:18:15 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I discovered one more thing...&lt;br/&gt;
It turns out strings like 1a1 or fine, it only affects things like 1a, 1b,1c -&amp;gt; &lt;br/&gt;
1f.  1g according to isNumber is false.  So, I believe the issue is that it &lt;br/&gt;
sees a number like 3b, and thinks it is hex!&lt;br/&gt;
Eric&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404408" author="phil@steitz.com" created="Fri, 6 Jun 2003 12:52:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Interesting. Are you sure about 1g, 2b, etc.?  These return true for me.  Looks&lt;br/&gt;
to me like anything will be accepted as the last character as long as all&lt;br/&gt;
charactres before it are numeric.&lt;/p&gt;
</comment>
                            <comment id="12404409" author="dep4b" created="Fri, 6 Jun 2003 13:03:40 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Interesting..  I don&apos;t know why I thought that.. I thought I had a testcase &lt;br/&gt;
that proved that a-f failed, g-z worked!&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;At any rate, I added this testcase:&lt;br/&gt;
 val = &quot;1z&quot;;&lt;br/&gt;
        assertTrue(&quot;isNumber(String) 15 Neg failed&quot;, !NumberUtils.isNumber&lt;br/&gt;
(val));&lt;br/&gt;
        assertTrue(&quot;isNumber(String)/createNumber(String) 15 Neg failed&quot;, !&lt;br/&gt;
checkCreateNumber(val));&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;and it tanked...  1z apparently is a number according to NumberUtils.isNumber!&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404410" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sun, 8 Jun 2003 21:22:41 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Patch applied (minor changes)&lt;br/&gt;
Thanks for spotting this one!&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404411" author="kochi@moon.hanya-n.org" created="Fri, 24 Oct 2003 12:40:44 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;How do you do. I also found such a thing.&lt;br/&gt;
The return value was true when &quot;1..&quot; was passed to NumberUtils.isNumber().&lt;br/&gt;
I think that I want &quot;1..&quot; to be false since it is not a numerical value.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-93] StackOverflow due to ToStringBuilder</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-93</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The ToStringBuilder doesn&apos;t handle relations to other objects&lt;br/&gt;
very well. It&apos;s very easy to get into an never-ending-loop.&lt;br/&gt;
The following code will crash the JVM with a StackOverflowError :&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;import org.apache.commons.lang.builder.ToStringBuilder;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public class Test1&lt;br/&gt;
{&lt;br/&gt;
  Test1 test;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  public Test1() {}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  public void setTest(Test1 test)&lt;/p&gt;
  {
    this.test = test;
  }

&lt;p&gt;  public String toString()&lt;/p&gt;
  {
    return ToStringBuilder.reflectionToString(this);
  }

&lt;p&gt;  public static void main(String[] args)&lt;/p&gt;
  {
    Test1 test1;
    Test1 test2;

    test1 = new Test1();
    test2 = new Test1();
    test1.setTest(test2);
    test2.setTest(test1);

    System.out.println(test1.toString());
  }
&lt;p&gt;}&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340527">LANG-93</key>
            <summary>StackOverflow due to ToStringBuilder</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="keeskuip@technologist.com">Kees Kuip</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sun, 2 Feb 2003 22:20:30 +0000</created>
                <updated>Sat, 20 May 2006 00:58:26 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Sat, 20 May 2006 00:58:26 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.0</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>1</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12403566" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Tue, 4 Feb 2003 07:36:18 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This example demonstrates that circular references in values, in this case, an &lt;br/&gt;
object pointing to itself, causes an infinite loop. Detecting a cycle in an &lt;br/&gt;
object graph is certainly possible but is it in the scope of the functionality &lt;br/&gt;
of this method? And if so, how should it be represented? &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403567" author="subterfusion@hotmail.com" created="Wed, 19 Feb 2003 20:54:09 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Maybe a safeReflectionToString(Object) method would be a good idea, which caches&lt;br/&gt;
the toString-ed objects and refuses to process any Object more than once.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403568" author="mparaz@mparaz.com" created="Fri, 28 Feb 2003 22:47:21 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;ToStringBuilder.reflectionToString() is static and creates a new&lt;br/&gt;
ToStringBuilder() on each call, with no knowledge of the previous calls. Thus&lt;br/&gt;
there&apos;s no way to maintain an object graph, keep state and &quot;remember&quot; what&lt;br/&gt;
objects have been appended to the StringBuffer. There&apos;s no way for us to know&lt;br/&gt;
that the toString() method will call reflectionToString() again. Am I right?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403569" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Fri, 14 Mar 2003 10:19:52 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I think you are correct since there is no object connection between &lt;br/&gt;
ToStringBuilder and an arbitrary object&apos;s toString method which may or may not &lt;br/&gt;
use ToStringBuilder. Would something like the nasty experiment below work in &lt;br/&gt;
all cases?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;package test;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;import java.util.HashMap;&lt;br/&gt;
import java.util.Map;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;import junit.framework.TestCase;&lt;br/&gt;
import org.apache.commons.lang.builder.ToStringBuilder;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;/**&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@author ggregory&lt;br/&gt;
 */&lt;br/&gt;
public class ToStringBuilderRTest extends TestCase {&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;    public void testMe() &lt;/p&gt;
{
        System.out.println(new NodeFixture());
        System.out.println(new NodeFixture(new NodeFixture(new NodeFixture
())));
        NodeFixture n = new NodeFixture();
        n.node = n;
        System.out.println(n);
        System.out.println(new NodeFixture(new NodeFixture(n)));
        assertEquals(&quot;RefectionToStringBuilder.registry.size() &amp;gt; 0&quot;, 
RefectionToStringBuilder.registry.size(), 0);
    }
&lt;p&gt;}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;class NodeFixture {&lt;br/&gt;
    public NodeFixture node;&lt;br/&gt;
    public NodeFixture() {&lt;br/&gt;
    }&lt;br/&gt;
    public NodeFixture(NodeFixture node) &lt;/p&gt;
{
        this.node = node;
    }
&lt;p&gt;    public String toString() &lt;/p&gt;
{
        return new RefectionToStringBuilder(this).toString();
    }
&lt;p&gt;}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;class RefectionToStringBuilder {&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    static Map registry = new HashMap();&lt;br/&gt;
    Object o;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    public RefectionToStringBuilder(Object o) &lt;/p&gt;
{
        this.o = o;
    }

&lt;p&gt;    public String toString() {&lt;br/&gt;
        String s;&lt;br/&gt;
        try {&lt;br/&gt;
            if (registry.containsKey(o)) &lt;/p&gt;
{
                return &quot;&amp;lt;cycle detected: &quot; + o.getClass().getName() + &quot;@&quot; + 
System.identityHashCode(o) + &quot;&amp;gt;&quot;;
            }
&lt;p&gt;            registry.put(o, null);&lt;br/&gt;
            s = ToStringBuilder.reflectionToString(o);&lt;br/&gt;
        } finally &lt;/p&gt;
{
            registry.remove(o);
        }
&lt;p&gt;        return s;&lt;br/&gt;
    }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;}&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403570" author="alex@apache.org" created="Fri, 14 Mar 2003 11:17:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;It might be better to use a ThreadLocal rather than a static to hold the         registry... In fact, it wouldn&apos;t need to be a Map, but a Set (maybe a HashSet) containing all objects currently being toStringed on this thread.   Also, why bother saying &quot;cycle detected&quot; &amp;#8211; why not just return the identity       code?  Like, for a foo that points to a bar and back again:             Foo@123[bar=Bar@456&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;foo=Foo@123&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;]            That&apos;s reasonably legible.              &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403571" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Fri, 14 Mar 2003 11:57:25 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thank you for your comments.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;gt;It might be better to use a ThreadLocal rather than a static to hold the &lt;br/&gt;
registry... &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Sure, we could do that. This was just a quick experiment, I did not give much &lt;br/&gt;
thought as to where the registry should live.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;gt;In fact, it wouldn&apos;t need to be a Map, but a Set (maybe a HashSet) containing &lt;br/&gt;
all objects currently being toStringed on this thread.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Absolutely, a Set makes sense.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;gt;Also, why bother saying &quot;cycle detected&quot; &amp;#8211; why not just return the &lt;br/&gt;
identitycode?  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It is indeed to verbose, the point of toString is not to detect cycles anyway.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I just updated the experiment with your sugestions. Since I have patched the &lt;br/&gt;
reflection code in the past, I&apos;ll take a stab at integrating this idea in &lt;br/&gt;
ToStringBuilder.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Since the ThreadLocal will only be used by the reflection methods, it is a bit &lt;br/&gt;
wasteful to have it in ToStringBuilder instead of a subclass but creating a &lt;br/&gt;
ReflectionToStringBuilder subclass might be over the top. I would like to &lt;br/&gt;
avoid further bloating the static side of ToStringBuilder...&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403572" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Fri, 14 Mar 2003 11:58:58 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=5333)&lt;br/&gt;
The above experiment, cleaned up.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403573" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Fri, 14 Mar 2003 12:00:00 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Well, not &quot;clean&quot; cleaned-up, just including Alex&apos;s suggestions.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403574" author="alex@apache.org" created="Fri, 14 Mar 2003 12:04:22 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Here&apos;s a failing unit test that I Wrote inside the existing &lt;br/&gt;
ToStringBuilderTest.  I wrote it as a-&amp;gt;b-&amp;gt;a instead of a-&amp;gt;a.&lt;br/&gt;
Maybe there&apos;s a need for both types of tests in the suite.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    static class ReflectionTestCycleA {&lt;br/&gt;
        ReflectionTestCycleB b;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        public String toString() &lt;/p&gt;
{
           return ToStringBuilder.reflectionToString(this);
        }&lt;br/&gt;
    }&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;br/&gt;
    static class ReflectionTestCycleB {&lt;br/&gt;
        ReflectionTestCycleA a;&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;br/&gt;
        public String toString() {           return ToStringBuilder.reflectionToString(this);        }
&lt;p&gt;    }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    public void testReflectionCycle() throws Exception&lt;/p&gt;
    {
        ReflectionTestCycleA a = new ReflectionTestCycleA();
        ReflectionTestCycleB b = new ReflectionTestCycleB();
        a.b = b;
        b.a = a;
        assertEquals( toBaseString(a) + &quot;[b=&quot; + toBaseString(b) + &quot;[a=&quot; + 
toBaseString(a) + &quot;]]&quot;,
                a.toString());
    }
</comment>
                            <comment id="12403575" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Thu, 27 Mar 2003 17:09:59 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This has been fixed with:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;ToStringBuilder.java 1.17&lt;br/&gt;
ToStringStyle.java 1.11&lt;br/&gt;
ToStringBuilderTest.java 1.7&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;A code review would be appreciated. Alex perhaps?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-92] [lang] DateUtils.parseCVS behavior parsing &quot;h:mm z&quot;</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-92</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;When DateUtils.parseCVS parses a time in &quot;h:mm z&quot; format, the resulting date is&lt;br/&gt;
1/1/1970. Is this appropriate, or would it be more appropriate for the resulting&lt;br/&gt;
date to be the current system date?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I don&apos;t know what the CVS behavior is.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows XP&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340890">LANG-92</key>
            <summary>[lang] DateUtils.parseCVS behavior parsing &quot;h:mm z&quot;</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="stevencaswell@apache.org">Steven Caswell</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 6 Aug 2003 18:48:10 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 6 Feb 2007 23:47:14 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 6 Feb 2007 23:47:14 +0000</resolved>
                                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12404805" author="bayard" created="Sun, 4 Jul 2004 12:04:20 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;cvs log -d &apos;23:50 EST&apos; NOTICE.txt&lt;br/&gt;
cvs &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;log aborted&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;: Can&apos;t parse date/time: 23:50 EST&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;However, if parseCVS can handle it, current System date seems to make the most&lt;br/&gt;
sense. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Nice comment for parseCVS:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    // TODO: Decide whether this code is removed or goes into 2.1&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If it used current System date, it would have to make sure it didn&apos;t get 24&lt;br/&gt;
hours off due to timezone confusion.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404806" author="stevencaswell@apache.org" created="Sun, 4 Jul 2004 23:14:40 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Since cvs doesn&apos;t parse just a time, maybe parseCVS should behave the same way.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404807" author="stevencaswell@apache.org" created="Mon, 12 Jul 2004 01:44:43 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The method needs further development. It has been moved into the DateFormatter&lt;br/&gt;
class in the lang sandbox. Accompanying test (testParseCVS) has been moved to&lt;br/&gt;
DateformatterTest.java in the lang sandbox.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>
                <customfields>
                                                                            <customfield id="customfield_12310310" key="com.atlassian.jira.toolkit:attachments">
                        <customfieldname>Attachment count</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>0.0</customfieldvalue>
                        </customfieldvalues>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-91] JavaDoc Errata</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-91</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Please note these (perhaps trivial) JavaDoc errors:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1 - org.apache.commons.lang.builder.ToStringBuilder:&lt;br/&gt;
&quot;To use this class write code as follows:&lt;br/&gt;
 public class Person {&lt;br/&gt;
   ...&lt;br/&gt;
   public String toString() {&lt;br/&gt;
     return new ToStringBuilder(this).&lt;br/&gt;
       append(name, &quot;name&quot;).     &amp;lt;--- wrong order of parameters ***&lt;br/&gt;
       append(age, &quot;age&quot;).       &amp;lt;--- wrong order of parameters ***&lt;br/&gt;
       append(smoker, &quot;smoker&quot;). &amp;lt;--- wrong order of parameters ***&lt;br/&gt;
       toString();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;2 - org.apache.commons.lang.builder.CompareToBuilder &lt;br/&gt;
&quot;Typical use for the code is as follows:&lt;br/&gt;
  public int **&lt;b&gt;comapareTo&lt;/b&gt;**(Object o) { &amp;lt;--- spelling of &quot;compareTo&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;3 - org.apache.commons.lang.ObjectUtils&lt;br/&gt;
&quot;public static final ObjectUtils.Null NULL&lt;br/&gt;
    Singleton ...&lt;br/&gt;
    Another example is **&lt;b&gt;HashTable&lt;/b&gt;** &amp;lt;--- spelling of &quot;Hashtable&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;(same thing in org.apache.commons.lang.ObjectUtils.Null)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks for the great work!&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>

cause them to always return 0 values.&lt;/p&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-89] NestableException/Delegate is not serializable</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-89</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Summary saids it all &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It means that server side exceptions cannot be &lt;br/&gt;
transfered/serialized to clients, which is a must have to inform users on errors and be able to do a &lt;br/&gt;
decent bughunt &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340403">LANG-89</key>
            <summary>NestableException/Delegate is not serializable</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-88] [PATCH] AdaptorRegistry</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-88</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;A while back, I discussed the AdaptorRegistry used throughout Tapestry.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Think of it as a &quot;smart Map&quot;, that connects arbitrary objects to a &quot;best-fit&quot; &lt;br/&gt;
adaptor by doing a search based on inheritance and implemented interfaces.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve created a patch from the jakarta-commons/lang/src.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This patch adds the org.apache.commons.lang.util.AdaptorRegistry (torn out of &lt;br/&gt;
Tapestry), plus a test suite.  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve run the entire commons-lang test suite succesfully.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Please get back to me if you decide to add this to commons-lang.  I think it &lt;br/&gt;
is a good fit.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340592">LANG-88</key>
            <summary>[PATCH] AdaptorRegistry</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-87] NullPointerException in CompareToBuilder</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-87</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;CompareToBuilder does not seem to handle nulls well at all.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In the methods:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public CompareToBuilder append(Object lhs, Object rhs)&lt;br/&gt;
public CompareToBuilder append(Object[] lhs, Object[] rhs)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If either the lhs or rhs parameters are null, the code is set up to throw a &lt;br/&gt;
NullPointerException instead of evaulating on the basis of null.  This requires &lt;br/&gt;
that all object be vetted before they be placed in a sorting collection, not &lt;br/&gt;
using the CompareToBuilder class, modifying the source code, or subclassing &lt;br/&gt;
CompareToBuilder.  We worked around this by subclassing CompareToBuilder and &lt;br/&gt;
overriding the methods in question.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The following lines of code (in both methods) are the cause of the exception:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        if (comparison != 0) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            return this;
        }&lt;br/&gt;
        if (lhs == rhs) {            return this;        }
&lt;p&gt;        if (lhs == null || rhs == null) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            throw new NullPointerException();
        }

&lt;p&gt;The &apos;if&apos; statement should be replaced with &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/help_16.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt; :&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        if (lhs == null &amp;amp;&amp;amp; rhs != null) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            comparison = -1;
            return this;
        }
&lt;p&gt;        if (lhs != null &amp;amp;&amp;amp; rhs == null) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            comparison = 1;
            return this;
        }</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340402">LANG-87</key>
            <summary>NullPointerException in CompareToBuilder</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="schloss@visi.com">schloss</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 7 Nov 2002 02:21:20 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:45:42 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:45:42 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.0</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12403180" author="yuri" created="Thu, 21 Nov 2002 17:30:14 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I came accross this bug as well, it really stops the CompareToBuilder being&lt;br/&gt;
useful and easy to use.  If there is a compelling reason why it shouldn&apos;t&lt;br/&gt;
support nulls (althogh it does when both null), then maybe a strict flag could&lt;br/&gt;
be added to another constructor, defaulting to strict in the no-args constructor.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Note, it aso affects the primitive array methods when they are called directly.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403181" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Mon, 9 Dec 2002 05:48:27 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I have recoded the class to handle nulls (nulls are low). Please retry the &lt;br/&gt;
class from the CVS and reopen the bug if you still have problems.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-86] [lang] FastDateFormat.getDateInstance(int, Locale)  always uses the pattern from the first invocation</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-86</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The first time calling FastDateFormat.getDateInstance(int style, Locale locale)&lt;br/&gt;
results in a correct stylepattern. Subsequent calls to the method with a&lt;br/&gt;
different locale does not return the stylepattern for the Locale - but the one&lt;br/&gt;
from the first invocation.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>

            <title>[LANG-85] [lang] [PATCH] fixes 75 typos</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-85</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The attached patch fixes 75 typos in the version of lang from 03-September-3.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340942">LANG-85</key>
            <summary>[lang] [PATCH] fixes 75 typos</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12404993" author="janekdb@yahoo.co.uk" created="Wed, 3 Sep 2003 18:56:18 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=8049)&lt;br/&gt;
patch file to fix 75 typos in lang&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

                            <comment id="12404995" author="bayard" created="Wed, 26 Apr 2006 13:10:52 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;2.1 released, closing.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-84] [lang] RandomStringUtils.randomAlpha methods omit &apos;z&apos;</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-84</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;RandomStringUtils.randomAlphabetic and randomAlphanumeric will never include the&lt;br/&gt;
letter &apos;z&apos; in a generated string. Similarly, randomAscii omits 127.  The&lt;br/&gt;
attached patch fixes this problem and also does the following:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1. Fixes an error in the javadoc description of random(int count, int start, int&lt;br/&gt;
end, boolean letters, boolean numbers, char[] set)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;2. Adds test cases to make sure that boundary characters (&apos;0&apos;, &apos;a&apos;, &apos;Z&apos;, etc.)&lt;br/&gt;
are included in generated strings.  The test cases will fail with the current&lt;br/&gt;
code, complaining that &apos;z&apos; and 127 are never generated.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;3. Changes the significance levels of the chi-square tests added earlier to&lt;br/&gt;
RandomUtilsTest.  The patch changes all significance levels to .001, which will&lt;br/&gt;
reduce the incidence of random failure to 1 in 1000.  They are currently all set&lt;br/&gt;
at .01.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340770">LANG-84</key>
            <summary>[lang] RandomStringUtils.randomAlpha methods omit &apos;z&apos;</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>

                            <comment id="12404421" author="tagunov@motor.ru" created="Mon, 9 Jun 2003 13:11:00 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;As a note from ousider ( not even familiear with the codebase and requirements)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;127, I beleive &lt;br/&gt;
is not ASCII, it has some special dreadfull meaning, like&lt;br/&gt;
erasing the prev character, but &lt;br/&gt;
anyway, I beleive it&apos;s not ASCII.&lt;/p&gt;

(If I recall ISO-2022 &lt;br/&gt;
correctly)&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404422" author="phil@steitz.com" created="Mon, 9 Jun 2003 13:55:55 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;That is a good point &amp;#8211; 127 should probably be excluded, since it is in any case&lt;br/&gt;
not printable. My mistake. The bound for this should be left as is in the code,&lt;br/&gt;
but it should be made clear in the javadoc that returned characters will be&lt;br/&gt;
between 32 and 126 inclusive. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-80] [lang] New class proposal: CharacterEncoding</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-80</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I propose the following new interface CharacterEncodingNames. I&apos;ve stored a&lt;br/&gt;
proposal in CVS to &quot;record&quot; it. Even if we nuke it, it will be in the &quot;Attic&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In short:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;/**&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Character encoding names required of every implementation of the Java platform.&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;According to the Java documentation &amp;lt;a&lt;br/&gt;
 *&lt;br/&gt;
href=&quot;http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.3/docs/api/java/lang/package-summary.html#charenc&quot;&amp;gt;JRE&lt;br/&gt;
character encoding names&amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;:&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&amp;lt;p&amp;gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&amp;lt;cite&amp;gt;Every implementation of the Java platform is required to support the&lt;br/&gt;
following character encodings. Consult the&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;release documentation for your implementation to see if any other encodings&lt;br/&gt;
are supported. &amp;lt;/cite&amp;gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&amp;lt;/p&amp;gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@see &amp;lt;a&lt;br/&gt;
href=&quot;http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.3/docs/api/java/lang/package-summary.html#charenc&quot;&amp;gt;JRE&lt;br/&gt;
character encoding&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;names &amp;lt;/a&amp;gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@author Apache Software Foundation&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@since 2.1&lt;br/&gt;
 */&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;
</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341597">LANG-80</key>
            <summary>[lang] New class proposal: CharacterEncoding</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="ggregory">Gary D. Gregory</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 27 Jul 2004 05:46:21 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 10 Mar 2011 22:30:42 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:22:58 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.1</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12407094" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Tue, 27 Jul 2004 05:47:09 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Assign to me if there is any work to do.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407095" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Tue, 27 Jul 2004 05:47:49 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=12229)&lt;br/&gt;
New class.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407096" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Tue, 27 Jul 2004 14:59:52 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;IMHO:&lt;br/&gt;
1) This should be a class, not an interface. Interfaces represent an API to an &lt;br/&gt;
object, not a set of constants. (see SystemUtils)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;2) These constants could fit on SystemUtils, eg ENCODING_UTF_8.&lt;br/&gt;
OR&lt;br/&gt;
The class name should be changed (it doesn&apos;t scan well due to the plural, &lt;br/&gt;
CharacterEncodingNames.UTF_8 kindof implies UTF8 is multiple names.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;3) I believe that there is a problem with encoding names in some earlier  JDKs, &lt;br/&gt;
where you must use &quot;UTF8&quot; not &quot;UTF-8&quot;. I believe all accept the short form.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;4) Maybe a new class here does make sense if we add methods to it.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public class CharacterEncodingUtils &lt;/p&gt;
{
// constants
 public static final UTF_8 = &quot;UTF8&quot;

 // methods
 public static String changeEncoding(str, from, to);
 }
&lt;p&gt;...&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407097" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Wed, 28 Jul 2004 01:24:23 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;&quot;1) This should be a class, not an interface. Interfaces represent an API to an &lt;br/&gt;
object, not a set of constants. (see SystemUtils)&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Agreed.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&quot;The class name should be changed (it doesn&apos;t scan well due to the plural, &lt;br/&gt;
CharacterEncodingNames.UTF_8 kindof implies UTF8 is multiple names.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This second pass calls the class CharacterEncoding and adds one method&lt;br/&gt;
isSupported(String). You now read: CharacterEncoding.UTF_8 which is a little better.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&quot;3) I believe that there is a problem with encoding names in some earlier  JDKs, &lt;br/&gt;
where you must use &quot;UTF8&quot; not &quot;UTF-8&quot;. I believe all accept the short form.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&quot;UTF-8&quot; works on 1.1.8_10, 1.2.2_017 and 1.3.1_11. Please see the new unit test.&lt;br/&gt;
Obviously, the method testMustBeSupportedJava1_3_1 does not pass on &amp;lt;1.3.1. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&quot;4) Maybe a new class here does make sense if we add methods to it.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I am keeping it as a separate class for now with the method noted above. A&lt;br/&gt;
method to &quot;change the encoding&quot; (toEncoding()?) I am not doing yet as I would&lt;br/&gt;
like to consider this possibly in the &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;codec&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; realm but maybe not. &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/wink.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407098" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Wed, 28 Jul 2004 01:25:00 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=12242)&lt;br/&gt;
Class CharacterEncoding&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407099" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Wed, 28 Jul 2004 01:25:30 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=12243)&lt;br/&gt;
Class CharacterEncodingTest&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407100" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Wed, 28 Jul 2004 01:27:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The attachement:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;07/26/04 22:47  New class.   (text/plain)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;is now obsolete.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407101" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Wed, 28 Jul 2004 03:54:00 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=12245)&lt;br/&gt;
CharacterEncodingTest version &quot;2&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407102" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Wed, 28 Jul 2004 03:55:49 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I noted initially, that I commited this to CVS, but I did not to benefit from an&lt;br/&gt;
initial review in this ticket. If approriate, it is ready for more tweakage and&lt;br/&gt;
I can put it in CVS.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407103" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Wed, 4 Aug 2004 00:16:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Comitted to CVS for further comments.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407104" author="bayard" created="Sun, 15 Aug 2004 09:28:05 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;My gut is to go with Stephen&apos;s SystemUtils suggestion or add more methods to&lt;br/&gt;
justify a new class.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407105" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Tue, 17 Aug 2004 01:08:38 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I think I see your POV but it feels to me like SystemUtils then becomes a bit of&lt;br/&gt;
dumping ground for this piece of functionality. The char encodings are not&lt;br/&gt;
something you&apos;d expect to find in the java.lang.System class. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;A separate class is more precise and also follows in the Java 1.4 direction. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I did not add extra methods to do this and that on purpose, a la XP, as I did&lt;br/&gt;
not need them and did not want to waste time (a la XP &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/wink.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt; then and in future&lt;br/&gt;
maintenance. If someone says &quot;I need a foo() method there&quot;, I&apos;d be happy to add it.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407106" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Fri, 20 Aug 2004 04:10:55 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I believe we should add a change method:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;changeEncoding(str, fromEncoding, toEncoding)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Then the class seems to fit.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407107" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Tue, 24 Aug 2004 03:29:43 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I could see a:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;String toString(string, newEncoding)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;but how does a &quot;from&quot; encoding work? The String object already is encoded (in&lt;br/&gt;
Unicode). Since a String is immutable and a new String object is created&lt;br/&gt;
&quot;toString&quot; would seem to make more sense. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407108" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Fri, 8 Oct 2004 05:42:34 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I found a comment about UTF-8 being bad on JDK1.1 prior to 1.1.8 somewhere &lt;br/&gt;
IIRC. Since thats pre &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;lang&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; supported JDKs, I am now happy with this.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Closing, so we can move on.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407109" author="bayard" created="Wed, 26 Apr 2006 13:11:03 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;2.1 released, closing.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-79] [lang] ReflectionToStringBuilder.toString(null) throws exception by design</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-79</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Calling ReflectionToStringBuilder.toString(null) throws an exception by design.&lt;br/&gt;
I  think it should just return null. Right now I need to do nasty things like:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    public String toString() &lt;/p&gt;
{
        // dive into commons http client object as they do not implement toString().
        return new ToStringBuilder(this).append(&quot;url&quot;,
this.url).append(&quot;retryCount&quot;, this.retryCount).append(
                &quot;multiThreadedHttpConnectionManager&quot;,
                this.multiThreadedHttpConnectionManager == null ? null :
ReflectionToStringBuilder
                        .toString(this.multiThreadedHttpConnectionManager)).append(
                &quot;secureProtocolSocketFactory&quot;,
                this.secureProtocolSocketFactory == null ? null :
ReflectionToStringBuilder
                        .toString(this.secureProtocolSocketFactory)).toString();
    }

&lt;p&gt;Will attach patch proposal.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341362">LANG-79</key>
            <summary>[lang] ReflectionToStringBuilder.toString(null) throws exception by design</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="ggregory">Gary D. Gregory</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 24 Mar 2004 02:05:37 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 2 May 2013 02:28:36 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:27:12 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.1</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12406332" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Wed, 24 Mar 2004 02:33:36 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Actually, passing null in should return the ToStringStyle nullText.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12406333" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Thu, 1 Jul 2004 01:23:59 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fixed in CVS.&lt;br/&gt;
ReflectionToStringBuilder.toString is now null-safe and returns the style&apos;s&lt;br/&gt;
nullText.&lt;br/&gt;
ToStringBuilder constructors are now null-safe. A new ToStringBuilder on a null&lt;br/&gt;
followed by a call to toString returns &quot;&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12406334" author="bayard" created="Wed, 26 Apr 2006 13:10:52 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;2.1 released, closing.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

                    </customfield>
                                                                <customfield id="customfield_12310920" key="com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-global-rank">
                        <customfieldname>Rank (Obsolete)</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>74896</customfieldvalue>
                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        </customfields>
    </item>


<item>
            <title>[LANG-78] StringUtils.chomp does not match Perl</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-78</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;In version 1.0.1, the method chomp(String) returns a value that is inconsistent &lt;br/&gt;
with Perl&apos;s function of the same name.  Since Perl invented the function chomp, &lt;br/&gt;
and since many developers will expect this method to behave the same, we should &lt;br/&gt;
bring it in line with expectations. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;There are also a cluster of related methods (chopNewline, prechomp, etc.) that &lt;br/&gt;
should be renamed/removed/deprecated to match expectations. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Specifically: &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Perl: &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;chop removes the final character, no matter what it is &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;chomp removes the final character if and only if it&apos;s a newline &lt;br/&gt;
(or, technically, the $INPUT_RECORD_SEPARATOR). &lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;Current StringUtils: &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;chop removes the final character, no matter what it is, and glomming &lt;br/&gt;
\r\n as if it were a single character &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;chopNewline removes the final character if and only if it&apos;s a newline &lt;br/&gt;
(glomming \r\n) &amp;#8211; behaving like Perl chomp &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;chomp removes the last newline &lt;b&gt;and all succeeding characters&lt;/b&gt; &lt;br/&gt;
(i.e. the last unterminated line) &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;chompLast removes the last character if and only if it&apos;s a newline &lt;br/&gt;
(glomming \r\n) &amp;#8211; This is redundant with chopNewline, and matches &lt;br/&gt;
Perl chomp &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;getChomp - since Henri&apos;s chomp might delete more than just the &lt;br/&gt;
separator, this returns the portion that got deleted&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340618">LANG-78</key>
            <summary>StringUtils.chomp does not match Perl</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
