<item>
            <title>[LANG-62] ArrayUtils.isEquals() throws ClassCastException when array1 and array2 are different dimension</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-62</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;ArrayUtils.isEquals() throws ClassCastException when array1 and array2 are &lt;br/&gt;
different dimension.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;For example:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;boolean[][] array1 = new boolean[][] { &lt;/p&gt;
{ true, false }, { true, false }
&lt;p&gt; };&lt;br/&gt;
boolean[] array2 = new boolean[] &lt;/p&gt;
{ false, true }
&lt;p&gt;;&lt;br/&gt;
if( ArrayUtils.isEquals( array1, array2 ) ){       // &amp;lt;== ClassCastException&lt;br/&gt;
      :&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;How about the following implementation to avoid the exception?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public static boolean isEquals(final Object array1, final Object array2) {&lt;br/&gt;
    if( !isSameType( array1, array2 ) ) return false;&lt;br/&gt;
    return new EqualsBuilder().append(array1, array2).isEquals();&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341655">LANG-62</key>
            <summary>ArrayUtils.isEquals() throws ClassCastException when array1 and array2 are different dimension</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="koji.sekiguchi@bluemartini.com">Koji Sekiguchi</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 24 Aug 2004 10:50:01 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:22:10 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:22:10 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.1</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12407319" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Thu, 26 Aug 2004 04:22:35 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This bug is really in EqualsBuilder.append(Object, Object). Fixed in CVS.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407320" author="bayard" created="Wed, 26 Apr 2006 13:11:00 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;2.1 released, closing.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>
                <customfields>
                                                                            <customfield id="customfield_12310310" key="com.atlassian.jira.toolkit:attachments">
                        <customfieldname>Attachment count</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>0.0</customfieldvalue>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-60] [lang] PMD is out of date</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-60</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;While building Commons-Lang 2.1 with &quot;maven site&quot; it attmepts to download PMD&lt;br/&gt;
1.9. This is quite old. I think the current versi0on is 3.2 or 3.3, Should be&lt;br/&gt;
easy enough to update.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342710">LANG-60</key>
            <summary>[lang] PMD is out of date</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>

                <created>Fri, 11 Nov 2005 03:20:20 +0000</created>

                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12410869" author="dennisl@apache.org" created="Sat, 12 Nov 2005 05:56:39 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This is not a commons-lang issue. Which version of PMD that Maven tries to&lt;br/&gt;
download is controlled by your installation of Maven. More specifically the&lt;br/&gt;
Maven PMD plug-in. If you upgrade that plug-in to the latest version (1.7) it&lt;br/&gt;
will use PMD 3.2.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;You can find instructions on how to upgrade your plug-in here:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://maven.apache.org/maven-1.x/reference/plugins/pmd/announcements/announcement-1.7.txt&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://maven.apache.org/maven-1.x/reference/plugins/pmd/announcements/announcement-1.7.txt&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-59] [lang] DateUtils.truncate method is buggy when dealing with DST switching hours</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-59</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Try to truncate 2004-10-31 01:00:00 MDT by hour and you&apos;ll actually get 2004-10-&lt;br/&gt;
31 01:00:00 MST, which is one hour after the input hour.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    // truncate 2004-10-31 01:00:00 MDT&lt;br/&gt;
    Date oct31_01MDT = new Date(1099206000000L);    &lt;br/&gt;
    Date result = DateUtils.truncate(oct31_01MDT, Calendar.HOUR_OF_DAY);&lt;br/&gt;
    assertEquals(oct31_01MDT, result);&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows XP&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342659">LANG-59</key>
            <summary>[lang] DateUtils.truncate method is buggy when dealing with DST switching hours</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="li.zhang@aeso.ca">Li Zhang</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 26 Oct 2005 07:22:00 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 27 Oct 2010 04:22:39 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Fri, 21 Jul 2006 05:15:42 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.1</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.2</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12417931" author="bayard" created="Tue, 27 Jun 2006 07:28:56 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Definitely a reproducable bug - not sure how to fix it though.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12419010" author="bayard" created="Tue, 4 Jul 2006 02:19:31 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Most frustatingly, sometimes the test passes and sometimes it fails. Possibly based on time of day the test is run.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12419165" author="li.zhang@aeso.ca" created="Wed, 5 Jul 2006 01:43:31 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I did a little hack and found this bug could be fixed with the following modification on DateUtils.modify method:&lt;br/&gt;
    private static void modify(Calendar val, int field, boolean round) {   &lt;br/&gt;
        ...&lt;br/&gt;
            if (!offsetSet) &lt;/p&gt;
{
                int min = val.getActualMinimum(fields[i][0]);
                int max = val.getActualMaximum(fields[i][0]);
                //Calculate the offset from the minimum allowed value
                offset = val.get(fields[i][0]) - min;
                //Set roundUp if this is more than half way between the minimum and maximum
                roundUp = offset &amp;gt; ((max - min) / 2);
            }
&lt;p&gt;            //We need to remove this field - Do nothing if there is no change&lt;br/&gt;
            if (offset != 0) &lt;/p&gt;
{     &amp;lt;--- add the check
            	val.set(fields[i][0], val.get(fields[i][0]) - offset);
  	    }
&lt;p&gt;        }&lt;br/&gt;
        throw new IllegalArgumentException(&quot;The field &quot; + field + &quot; is not supported&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
   }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Calendar.set method resets some fields (e.g., DST_OFFSET) even if the new value is the same as the old value.  We just need to add a check before setting the new value to a field. If there is no change on this field, do not call Calendar.set method.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12419167" author="bayard" created="Wed, 5 Jul 2006 01:58:58 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Many thanks - any thoughts on why the test case only fails some of the time?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12419168" author="li.zhang@aeso.ca" created="Wed, 5 Jul 2006 02:01:14 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Forget my previous post. The fix is broken. The problem is sometimes when you call Calendar.set method the DST_OFFSET field is reset to 0.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12421376" author="niallp" created="Sun, 16 Jul 2006 05:19:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The problem seems to be with java.util.Calendar - as soon as it re-calculates the milliseconds it adjusts the time - even if you set a field without actually changing the value(i.e. set it to the same value) the same thing happens - it adds an hour to the time (see test case which demonstrates this).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m attaching a pragmatic, but not very elegant solution that works for truncating (and rounding down) - rather than using the Calendar methods to adjust milliseconds, seconds and minutes it adjusts the Date&apos;s millisecond value directly. Its only fields down to the &quot;hour&quot; level that affect the date - so truncating milliseconds, seconds and minutes should work fine since they will still be the same date. Combined with Li Zhang&apos;s suggestion of only setting fields which have changed - this seems to work.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12421377" author="bayard" created="Sun, 16 Jul 2006 05:35:38 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Very, very cool. Patch applied locally and passes tests. Will run the tests a few times through the day tomorrow as they tend to pass in the evening (I think) anyway. If it survives tomorrow, I&apos;ll apply the fix.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12422549" author="bayard" created="Fri, 21 Jul 2006 05:15:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Niall&apos;s fix seems to be working &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt; Passed tests in morning and evening which seemed to have some impact on the bug.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Please reopen if it&apos;s not working for you, Li.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12422554" author="bayard" created="Fri, 21 Jul 2006 05:46:39 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Now I&apos;ve actually done the commit. Doh.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt; svn ci -m &quot;Adding Niall&apos;s fix for &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-59&quot; title=&quot;[lang] DateUtils.truncate method is buggy when dealing with DST switching hours&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-59&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;LANG-59&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; - an edge case in date truncation - and his enhancement for the unit test that was there. &quot; src/&lt;br/&gt;
Sending        src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/time/DateUtils.java&lt;br/&gt;
Sending        src/test/org/apache/commons/lang/time/DateUtilsTest.java&lt;br/&gt;
Transmitting file data ..&lt;br/&gt;
Committed revision 424192.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Should be in tonight&apos;s nightly build:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://people.apache.org/repository/commons-lang/jars/commons-lang-20060721.jar&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://people.apache.org/repository/commons-lang/jars/commons-lang-20060721.jar&lt;/a&gt;  &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12922604" author="maximocapo" created="Tue, 19 Oct 2010 16:19:39 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I can&#180;t find &lt;a href=&quot;http://people.apache.org/repository/commons-lang/jars/commons-lang-20060721.jar&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://people.apache.org/repository/commons-lang/jars/commons-lang-20060721.jar&lt;/a&gt;, the site doesn&apos;t exist. Anybody could said me which is the version that contains the fix ?? I&apos;ve ran with versions 2.1, 2.2 and it still fails when I try to make truncated  dealing with DST switching hours.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;UNTRUNCATED DATE 2010-10-10 05:16:14.0&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;After truncated date with :   DateUtils.truncate(scaTransaction.getFechaTrx(),&lt;br/&gt;
					Calendar.DATE);&lt;br/&gt;
The result is:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;TRUNCATED DATE Sat Oct 09 23:00:00 CLT 2010&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12922864" author="bayard" created="Wed, 20 Oct 2010 06:08:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This change should have been fixed in 2.2, though it&apos;d be best to test on 2.4 and then let us know if you&apos;re still having trouble in a new JIRA issue.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12923289" author="maximocapo" created="Thu, 21 Oct 2010 02:31:12 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The problem persist in both versions: 2.4 and 2.5&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;DateUtils.trucate() does not work properly with daylight saving time.&lt;br/&gt;
e.g.:&lt;br/&gt;
Date: 2010/10/10 05:16:14.0&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;DateUtils.truncate(date, Calendar.DATE) : Sun Oct 10 01:00:00 CLST 2010&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Instead of showing 10/10/2010, it shows 10/10/2010 01:00:00&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

                        <customfieldvalues>

                    </customfield>
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        <customfield id="customfield_10010" key="com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:importid">
                        <customfieldname>Bugzilla Id</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>37243</customfieldvalue>

            <title>[LANG-58] [lang] HashCodeBuilder does not use the same values as Boolean for boolean.</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-58</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;HashCodeBuilder uses 0 and 1 instead of the values used by Boolean (1231 and 1237).&lt;/p&gt;</description>

            <title>[LANG-57] [lang] ClassCastException in Enum.equals(Object)</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-57</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Getting a ClassCastException if i&lt;br/&gt;
runnig this snippet&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;ColorEnum.RED.equals(&quot;test&quot;)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Windows XP&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341236">LANG-57</key>
            <summary>[lang] ClassCastException in Enum.equals(Object)</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="schroeder@dakosy.de">Schroeder</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 3 Feb 2004 04:39:57 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 2 May 2013 02:28:36 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:29:45 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.1</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12405905" author="brentworden" created="Tue, 10 Feb 2004 07:08:29 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=10289)&lt;br/&gt;
patch adds instanceof check to Enum.equals().&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405906" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Thu, 12 Feb 2004 04:28:27 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Does this patch work with the intended feature of the &quot;} catch&lt;br/&gt;
(ClassCastException ex) &lt;/p&gt;
{&quot; block? Is there a unit test that checks the &quot;}
&lt;p&gt; catch&lt;br/&gt;
(ClassCastException ex) {&quot; behavior?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405907" author="brentworden" created="Thu, 12 Feb 2004 05:01:41 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I changed the Enum.equals method to avoid cast exceptions.  The thought being, &lt;br/&gt;
an equality check between objects of different types should return false and &lt;br/&gt;
not raise an exception.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The unit test assures a ClassCastException is not thrown when comparing objects &lt;br/&gt;
of different types.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;FYI, by different types I mean objects that fail an instanceof check.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405908" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Thu, 12 Feb 2004 06:38:32 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The issue is that it looks like the author of the code had clear intentions when&lt;br/&gt;
writting the catch block, which this patch seems to circumvent. What that last&lt;br/&gt;
else and catch blcok do is allow Enum instance to work even though they might&lt;br/&gt;
come  from different class loaders. I think your patch might break this feature.&lt;br/&gt;
I also do not think there is a unit test that validates this feature. So, that&lt;br/&gt;
would be the first thing to do: add a unit test that checks that Enums from&lt;br/&gt;
different class loaders can be tested.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405909" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Thu, 12 Feb 2004 08:46:35 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fixed as a side effect of fixing 26876. Added a unit test for this case.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405910" author="bayard" created="Wed, 26 Apr 2006 13:11:02 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;2.1 released, closing.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-56] StringUtils.countMatches loops forever if substring empty</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-56</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;If you do say StringUtils.countMatches(&quot;x&quot;, &quot;&quot;), then it goes into an infinite loop.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Also sub isn&apos;t checked for null if str is null also. For instance&lt;br/&gt;
StringUtils.countMatches(null, null) should throw an NPE instead of 0.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;To fix both problems put the following code at the start of the method:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        if (sub.equals(&quot;&quot;)) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            return 0;
        }</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Linux&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340434">LANG-56</key>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-55] RandomStringUtils infloops with length &lt; 1</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-55</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The various random* methods in RandomStringUtils go into an infinite loop when&lt;br/&gt;
the length of the requested String is &amp;lt; 1.  I&apos;ll attach a patch.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340637">LANG-55</key>
            <summary>RandomStringUtils infloops with length &lt; 1</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="ville.skytta@iki.fi">Ville Skytt&#228;</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sat, 5 Apr 2003 04:40:57 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:41:29 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:41:29 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.0</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12403957" author="ville.skytta@iki.fi" created="Sat, 5 Apr 2003 04:42:10 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=5652)&lt;br/&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-54] [lang] [PATCH] NumberRange - adds inclusive and exclusive end points</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-54</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;This patch updates Test cases for NumberRange and also adds exclusive and&lt;br/&gt;
inclusive endpoints to NumberRange.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341030">LANG-54</key>
            <summary>[lang] [PATCH] NumberRange - adds inclusive and exclusive end points</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="tobrien@discursive.com">Tim O&apos;Brien</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sun, 12 Oct 2003 06:34:22 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 16 Oct 2013 08:55:00 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 6 Feb 2007 23:47:11 +0000</resolved>
                                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12405266" author="tobrien@discursive.com" created="Sun, 12 Oct 2003 06:35:33 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=8535)&lt;br/&gt;
patch for NumberRange.java and NumberRangeTest.java&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405267" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sat, 29 Nov 2003 21:59:47 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This seems like a reasonable extension to the API, however it does add a level &lt;br/&gt;
of complexity. Is this now covered by &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;math&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Also, the patch would affect Serialization, so this needs to be thought about.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405268" author="phil@steitz.com" created="Sun, 27 Jun 2004 13:35:13 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;In response to Stephen&apos;s comment, we have nothing like this in &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;math&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I am -0 on this change, however, for the following reasons.&lt;br/&gt;
First, as Stephen points out, the change would affect serialization. Second,&lt;br/&gt;
while the extension makes sense logically, I am not sure that is has tremendous&lt;br/&gt;
practical value.  For integer ranges, (a,b) is no different from &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;a+1, b-1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; &amp;#8211;&lt;br/&gt;
i.e., being able to specify &quot;inclusivity&quot; does not really buy you anything other&lt;br/&gt;
than convenience (at the expense of a more complicated API and some overhead). &lt;br/&gt;
For floating point ranges, counting on the difference between (a,b) and &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;a,b&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
would in most cases I can imagine be dangerous &amp;#8211; so here again, the extension&lt;br/&gt;
does not really buy you anything.  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I may of course be missing some important and valuable use cases, in which case&lt;br/&gt;
I will happily move to +0 once I know what they are.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405269" author="tobrien@discursive.com" created="Sun, 27 Jun 2004 23:15:35 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I&apos;ve marked this as WONTFIX.  I had a reason to use something like this, but &lt;br/&gt;
in the meantime, I&apos;ve solved this problem through other means.  I do agree &lt;br/&gt;
with Phil that this adds unnecessary complexity in Math at a time when math &lt;br/&gt;
should be reaching a point of stability.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                            <attachment id="12332578" name="ASF.LICENSE.NOT.GRANTED--patch.txt" size="16384" author="tobrien@discursive.com" created="Sun, 12 Oct 2003 06:35:33 +0000"/>
                    </attachments>

            <title>[LANG-53] SystemUtils.IS_OS_OS2 Javadoc is wrong</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-53</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The javadoc says &quot;Mac&quot; instead of &quot;OS/2&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340857">LANG-53</key>
            <summary>SystemUtils.IS_OS_OS2 Javadoc is wrong</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="ggregory">Gary D. Gregory</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>

                <updated>Wed, 16 Oct 2013 08:55:05 +0000</updated>

                            <comment id="12404716" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Fri, 18 Jul 2003 23:51:14 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Source: &lt;br/&gt;
----&lt;del&gt;Original Message&lt;/del&gt;----&lt;br/&gt;
From: KANEUCHI Tetsuya &lt;span class=&quot;nobr&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;mailto:tetsuyak@ka2.so-net.ne.jp&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;tetsuyak@ka2.so-net.ne.jp&lt;sup&gt;&lt;img class=&quot;rendericon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/mail_small.gif&quot; height=&quot;12&quot; width=&quot;13&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/span&gt; &lt;br/&gt;
Sent: Friday, July 18, 2003 08:12&lt;br/&gt;
To: commons-dev@jakarta.apache.org&lt;br/&gt;
Subject: &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;lang&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; 2.0RC SystemUtils.IS_OS_OS2&apos;s JavaDoc is wrong.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I found small mistake in Commons Lang 2.0RC1.&lt;br/&gt;
SystemUtils.IS_OS_OS2&apos;s javadoc says &quot;if this is Mac.&quot;&lt;br/&gt;
It should be &quot;OS/2&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;RCS file: /home/cvspublic/jakarta-commons/lang/src/java/org/apache/commons/lang/&lt;br/&gt;
SystemUtils.java,v&lt;br/&gt;
retrieving revision 1.17&lt;br/&gt;
diff -u -r1.17 SystemUtils.java&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;#8212; SystemUtils.java    8 Jul 2003 05:59:58 -0000       1.17&lt;br/&gt;
+++ SystemUtils.java    18 Jul 2003 15:03:21 -0000&lt;br/&gt;
@@ -185,7 +185,7 @@&lt;br/&gt;
     public static final boolean IS_OS_MAC_OSX = getOSMatches(&quot;Mac OS X&quot;);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;     /**&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul class=&quot;alternate&quot; type=&quot;square&quot;&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;* &amp;lt;p&amp;gt;Is &amp;lt;code&amp;gt;true&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt; if this is Mac.&amp;lt;/p&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
+     * &amp;lt;p&amp;gt;Is &amp;lt;code&amp;gt;true&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt; if this is OS/2.&amp;lt;/p&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
      *&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&amp;lt;p&amp;gt;The field will return &amp;lt;code&amp;gt;false&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt; if &amp;lt;code&amp;gt;OS_NAME&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
is&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;&amp;lt;code&amp;gt;null&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt;.&amp;lt;/p&amp;gt;&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;&amp;#8211;&lt;br/&gt;
KANEUCHI Tetsuya&lt;/p&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-52] [lang] Validate.notNull should throw NullArgumentException</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-52</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Validate.notNull throws a IllegalArgumentException but should throw a&lt;br/&gt;
NullArgumentException&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342593">LANG-52</key>
            <summary>[lang] Validate.notNull should throw NullArgumentException</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="5" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/trivial.svg">Trivial</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="joerg@myndian.de">J&#246;rg Gottschling</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sat, 1 Oct 2005 21:11:24 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 17 Dec 2009 03:41:06 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 11 Aug 2009 06:32:59 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>3.0</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12410505" author="joerg@myndian.de" created="Sat, 1 Oct 2005 22:22:53 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Perhaps Validate.notEmpty should also throw NullArgumentException if the&lt;br/&gt;
Argument was null.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12410506" author="jwcarman" created="Sun, 2 Oct 2005 00:24:45 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;What is NullArgumentException?  Do you mean NullPointerException?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12410507" author="jwcarman" created="Sun, 2 Oct 2005 00:29:45 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Changing these methods to throw a different exception type could break existing&lt;br/&gt;
code that depends on the fact that they throw IllegalArgumentException.  What if&lt;br/&gt;
someone (even if it&apos;s not suggested) puts a try/catch around a call to&lt;br/&gt;
Validate.notNull() which catches IllegalArgumentException?  For most cases&lt;br/&gt;
you&apos;re not really supposed to catch runtime exceptions, but that doesn&apos;t mean&lt;br/&gt;
that it&apos;s not done.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12410508" author="joerg@myndian.de" created="Sun, 2 Oct 2005 02:49:09 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;For NullArgumentException see here:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;a href=&quot;http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/lang/api/org/apache/commons/lang/NullArgumentException.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/lang/api/org/apache/commons/lang/NullArgumentException.html&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It&apos;s in the same package als Validate and a subclass of&lt;br/&gt;
IllegalArgumentException, so it is no Problem to change this.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12410509" author="jwcarman" created="Sun, 2 Oct 2005 11:20:23 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Ahhh.  I was looking in the exception package and didn&apos;t see it.  This shouldn&apos;t&lt;br/&gt;
cause any problems, then, I wouldn&apos;t think.  Good idea!&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12410510" author="joerg@myndian.de" created="Mon, 3 Oct 2005 02:38:05 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Hm, but there would be little difference in the use of&lt;br/&gt;
Validate.notNull(Object,String) and the Methods notEmpty with take an message as&lt;br/&gt;
second argument. At the moment I write something like:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public void foo(Object bar){&lt;br/&gt;
  Validate.notNull(bar, &quot;bar was null&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
  //other code&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;But if notNull would throw an NullArgumentException you should write &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public void foo(Object bar){&lt;br/&gt;
  Validate.notNull(bar, &quot;bar&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
  //other code&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Or you would get &quot;bar was null must not be null.&quot; as message. &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;BTW: Perhaps I want to provide some methods to this class (Validate). What do I&lt;br/&gt;
have to do? (Or should I create an issue for every new method?)&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12410511" author="bayard" created="Sat, 15 Apr 2006 06:21:12 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Sorry for lateness in replying J&#246;rg. If you still wanted to do such, multiple&lt;br/&gt;
attachments to the one issue is fine. If the attachments started to involve&lt;br/&gt;
different classes, packages, or problems, then I&apos;d be tempted to kick off a new&lt;br/&gt;
issue.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12410512" author="bayard" created="Mon, 24 Apr 2006 14:06:19 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;API change, so targetted for 3.0 (which hopefully will be pretty quickly after&lt;br/&gt;
2.2). &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12444520" author="bayard" created="Tue, 24 Oct 2006 21:30:04 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The only problem with this is in the messages. The NullArgumentException automatically adds &quot; must not be null&quot; to the end of any message passed up to it (ACK). In Validate we receive the message to print out, so having &quot; must not be null&quot; on the end becomes very daft. Credit to whomever wrote the unit tests that failed; otherwise I wouldn&apos;t have noticed.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;We should also change the noNullElements methods if we do change the notNull ones, but I think the gain here is not worth the pain.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m +1 to WONTFIX this.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12444522" author="bayard" created="Tue, 24 Oct 2006 21:31:52 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;In case we do do this, a patch with the changes to Validate.java.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12461424" author="scolebourne" created="Fri, 29 Dec 2006 18:20:51 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Yes, this method probably should have thrown NullArgumentException, but it doesn&apos;t and its too late to fix now. Also, the JDK should have has a NullArgumentException, but there&apos;s not much we can do about that either.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12512692" author="bayard" created="Sat, 14 Jul 2007 08:45:24 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Reopening this issue for 3.0 - backwards compatible changes might be acceptable then.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12512757" author="pbenedict" created="Sat, 14 Jul 2007 23:43:40 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This can be fixed in the 2.x line. Add a second constructor to NullArgumentException which accepts both the name of the offending field and the message. Because the name isn&apos;t provided by Validate, just pass in null for it, but if it exists you can append both messages together. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12539903" author="bayard" created="Sat, 3 Nov 2007 08:11:24 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Paul: Got patch? &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12539917" author="scolebourne" created="Sat, 3 Nov 2007 11:09:15 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Just so we are clear. This change could break compatibility:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;try {&lt;br/&gt;
. Validate.notNull(obj);&lt;br/&gt;
. someMethodThatMightThrowNullArgumentException()&lt;br/&gt;
} catch (NullArgumentException ex) {&lt;br/&gt;
. System.out.println(&quot;A&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
} catch (IllegalArgumentException ex) {&lt;br/&gt;
. System.out.println(&quot;B&quot;);&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Making this change will cause the code to print A instead of B.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12540147" author="pbenedict" created="Mon, 5 Nov 2007 08:21:12 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Stephen, was that only an FYI or an objection? &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12540156" author="scolebourne" created="Mon, 5 Nov 2007 09:19:38 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I won&apos;t block the change, but I personally disagree with it for compatibility reasons.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12541250" author="bayard" created="Fri, 9 Nov 2007 07:54:49 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Pushing back up to 3.0. I&apos;m glad we discussed this again - and I think while it&apos;s worth doing, there&apos;s no rush to do it before we hit the next major release.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12595879" author="bayard" created="Sun, 11 May 2008 05:07:42 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Moving to LangTwo which will most likely be a different package structure. It&apos;s not a big enough deal to be a point of backwards incompatibility.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12605323" author="pbenedict" created="Mon, 16 Jun 2008 15:45:01 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I still vote for this to be in 3.0. You can achieve it by adding a new Validate.notNullArgument method which appropriately throws NullArgumentException. This way, you can keep both backwards compatibility, but also deprecate the current version.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12741715" author="bayard" created="Tue, 11 Aug 2009 06:32:59 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Won&apos;t fix because we deleted NullArgumentException.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-51] Typo in documentation</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-51</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;There is a small typo in the documentation at the URL:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/lang/api/org/apache/commons/lang/SystemUtils.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/lang/api/org/apache/commons/lang/SystemUtils.html&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The description for the static boolean IS_JAVA_1_5 is &quot;True iff this is Java&lt;br/&gt;
version 1.3.&quot;.  I presume the version number really should be &quot;1.5&quot; rather than&lt;br/&gt;
&quot;1.3&quot;.&lt;/p&gt;</description>

            <title>[LANG-50] [lang] Replace Clover with Cobertura</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-50</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I attempted to run &quot;maven site&quot; but it failed like this:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Attempting to download clover-ant-1.3_01.jar.&lt;br/&gt;
1303K downloaded&lt;br/&gt;
Attempting to download clover-30day-eval-1.0.license.&lt;br/&gt;
WARNING: Failed to download clover-30day-eval-1.0.license.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;BUILD FAILED&lt;br/&gt;
File...... /Users/elharo/.maven/cache/maven-xdoc-plugin-1.8/plugin.jelly&lt;br/&gt;
Element... attainGoal&lt;br/&gt;
Line...... 687&lt;br/&gt;
Column.... 48&lt;br/&gt;
The build cannot continue because of the following unsatisfied dependency:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Clover is a nice tool, but it is closed source, and probably not available to&lt;br/&gt;
everyone. I suggest replacing it with Cobertura, whcih is open source and does&lt;br/&gt;
90% of what Clover does.&lt;/p&gt;</description>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-49] Specify initial size for Enum&apos;s HashMap.</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-49</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Default size of Enum&apos;s HashMap needs improvement.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://marc.theaimsgroup.com/?l=jakarta-commons-dev&amp;amp;m=104316379302781&amp;amp;w=2&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://marc.theaimsgroup.com/?l=jakarta-commons-dev&amp;amp;m=104316379302781&amp;amp;w=2&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340529">LANG-49</key>
            <summary>Specify initial size for Enum&apos;s HashMap.</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="bayard">Henri Yandell</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Mon, 3 Feb 2003 15:35:21 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:43:02 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:43:02 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.0</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12403576" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Wed, 5 Feb 2003 02:42:38 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I have applied the patch, however I have changed 89 to 61.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;JDK1.4 uses powers of two internally and does not default to size 101. 61 &lt;br/&gt;
should scale in JDK1.4 to size 64, and yet is still a prime number for JDK1.2 &lt;br/&gt;
and 1.3.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Perhaps you could test this?&lt;br/&gt;
Stephen&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>

                    </attachments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-48] static option for reversing the stacktrace</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-48</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The nestableDelegate dumps the stacktrace bottomup instead of topdown as is the custom in the JDK &lt;br/&gt;
(especially in JDK 1.4&apos;s own chained exceptions).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thus when using NestableException you &lt;br/&gt;
will always see the first low-level exception (e.g. an Null Exception) and you&apos;ll have to go all the &lt;br/&gt;
way to the bottom to see the highlevel exception (e.g. an HibernateQueryException: Error while &lt;br/&gt;
parsing query at &apos;s.count()&apos;)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This is not very friendly to users because hopefully the &lt;br/&gt;
highlevel exception will be the best explanation in 9 out of 10 causes, it is only when debugging or &lt;br/&gt;
in misbehaved exception handling one like to see the root causes - and THEN one can go down and read &lt;br/&gt;
the bottom of the stack trace.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thus, I would suggest that you make it possible to have &lt;br/&gt;
NestableDelegate print the stacktrace in reverce so the highlevel exception get printed first &lt;br/&gt;
and THEN the lower-levels.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;And optimal one could set an &lt;br/&gt;
NestableDelegate.printStackTraceTopDown=true as an system property so one could choose &lt;br/&gt;
which strategy should be activated in the system. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Am I making any sense ? &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340404">LANG-48</key>
            <summary>static option for reversing the stacktrace</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="max@eos.dk">Max Rydahl Andersen</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 7 Nov 2002 23:41:04 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:45:38 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:45:38 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.0</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12403185" author="alex@apache.org" created="Mon, 31 Mar 2003 00:26:21 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;&quot;This is not very friendly to users because hopefully the &lt;br/&gt;
highlevel exception will be the best explanation in 9 out of 10 causes,&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This is contrary to my experience.  I find that the higher level exceptions &lt;br/&gt;
usually cloud the issue, obscuring a low-level explanation (e.g. Disk Full) &lt;br/&gt;
with an package-level explanation (e.g. StorageLayerException) that was layered &lt;br/&gt;
on in order to satisfy Java&apos;s neurotic exception checking.  In addition, this &lt;br/&gt;
high-level exception has the &lt;b&gt;wrong&lt;/b&gt; stack trace, since it was thrown from a &lt;br/&gt;
different line of code than the one that caused the error; so you &lt;b&gt;have&lt;/b&gt; to &lt;br/&gt;
scroll down and then seek back up again to find the start of the real stack &lt;br/&gt;
trace.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&quot;it is only when debugging or in misbehaved exception handling one like to see &lt;br/&gt;
the root causes - and THEN one can go down and read the bottom of the stack &lt;br/&gt;
trace.&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I disagree with this statement too.  While I do believe that users should be &lt;br/&gt;
given information when something goes wrong, naive users should never be forced &lt;br/&gt;
to read a stack trace or an exception message.  For them, &lt;b&gt;any&lt;/b&gt; exception at &lt;br/&gt;
all translates as &quot;Something bad happened (plus technical gobbledegook).&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;That means that the &lt;b&gt;only&lt;/b&gt; users interested in the content would presumably &lt;br/&gt;
only be interested because they are debugging.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;It sounds like the bug reporter needs to install a higher-level error handling &lt;br/&gt;
routine in his application.  While throwables can be a nice way to signal &lt;br/&gt;
application errors, there needs to be a different way for your application to &lt;br/&gt;
figure out what message to present to the user.  This can be as simple as &quot;An &lt;br/&gt;
error occured while X&quot; where X is &quot;Loading foo.xml&quot; or &quot;Communicating with the &lt;br/&gt;
server&quot;, and you can even generate these by looking at the high-level exception &lt;br/&gt;
and having a mapping table of your own (StorageLayerException -&amp;gt; &quot;Accessing the &lt;br/&gt;
local disk&quot;) but displaying &quot;com.myapp.storage.StorageLayerException: ...&quot; to &lt;br/&gt;
the user is already assuming she&apos;s technical enough to even bother reading it &lt;br/&gt;
past the &quot;com.myapp.&quot;, let alone comprehend it.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;After all that, however, I&apos;m not sure what the correct default behavior is for &lt;br/&gt;
lang.exception.  There is a very strong argument that it should behave just &lt;br/&gt;
like JDK; if so, there&apos;s another argument that there should be an option to &lt;br/&gt;
reverse it for people like me who prefer it upside-down.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;All IMHO, of course... &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403186" author="max@eos.dk" created="Mon, 31 Mar 2003 00:51:13 +0000"  >

&lt;p&gt;&quot;It sounds like the bug reporter needs to install a higher-level error handling &lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;routine in his application.&quot; &lt;/p&gt;




&lt;p&gt;&lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;




&lt;p&gt;I got a higher-level error handling routine which &quot;converts&quot; the correct message &lt;br/&gt;
to end-users.&lt;/p&gt;




&lt;p&gt;In my bug-report the word users was ment as &quot;developers&quot; which is the users of &lt;br/&gt;
the NestedException.&lt;/p&gt;




&lt;p&gt;And yes, I understand your viewpoint of the Disk full is better than &lt;br/&gt;
StorageException.....but as I wrote, if the top-level exception isn&apos;t good &lt;br/&gt;
enough then it is because of a &quot;mis-behaving&quot; application/exception hierachy.&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;Thus if you got a good exception hierachy you write the correct message in the &lt;br/&gt;
top-level exception (e.g. DerefrenceException(&quot;Could not derefence property &lt;br/&gt;
&apos;kitten&apos; on Person&quot;)) and embed the Nullpointer exception that indicated it &lt;br/&gt;
inside the top-level exception.&lt;/p&gt;




&lt;p&gt;In this case it is much more meaningfull to see the DereferenceException than &lt;br/&gt;
the nullpointer exception. If the nullpointer exception is at the top, one &lt;br/&gt;
thinks it is a nasty bug...if DereferenceExcpeiton is at the top you know what &lt;br/&gt;
has happend and it is a valid exception (if you have tried to dereference &lt;br/&gt;
&apos;kitten&apos; on Person at least &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;




&lt;p&gt;But I would also prefer to have it as an option &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;









</comment>
                            <comment id="12403187" author="mohankishore@yahoo.com" created="Fri, 11 Apr 2003 09:30:29 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=5784)&lt;br/&gt;
Allows jdk1.4 like trace&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403188" author="mohankishore@yahoo.com" created="Fri, 11 Apr 2003 09:36:38 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Have attached a patch which allows one to simulate the stack trace in jdk1.4.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Added a couple of boolean attributes:&lt;br/&gt;
1) topDown - &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;true&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; prints the stack top down&lt;br/&gt;
2) trimStackFrames - &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;true&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; removes the repeated frames in nested exceptions&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Also added a method to ExceptionUtils to detect if Throwable class has a &lt;br/&gt;
getCause method. If so, the printStackTrace just uses that. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The way it is implemented right now, the output looks very garbled in jdk1.4...&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403189" author="mohankishore@yahoo.com" created="Wed, 30 Apr 2003 04:01:59 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The patch will cause the tests to fail. Please let me know if the basic idea is &lt;br/&gt;
acceptable - can then go ahead with the test cases (will require a complete &lt;br/&gt;
overhaul of the test cases). The test cases would have to run in both jre1.3 &lt;br/&gt;
and jre1.4...&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403190" author="mohankishore@yahoo.com" created="Tue, 6 May 2003 02:00:52 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=6223)&lt;br/&gt;
Source and Test pacthes&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403191" author="bayard" created="Wed, 14 May 2003 10:01:40 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Mohan&apos;s patch applied. Tests succeed.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-47] test.lang fails if compiled with non iso-8859-1 locales</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-47</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Linux platform JDK 1.4.1_02&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;$ export LANG=C ; ant clean &amp;amp;&amp;amp; ant dist &amp;amp;&amp;amp; ant test&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;test.lang:&lt;br/&gt;

     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; ...........................F.F&lt;br/&gt;
     &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;java&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; Time: 0.402&lt;br/&gt;

&lt;p&gt;[ this one works ]&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;LANG&apos;s setting for &quot;ant test&quot; does not appear to matter.  If LANG=C for &quot;ant&lt;br/&gt;
dist&quot;, &quot;ant test&quot; will fail even if LANG=en_US.&lt;/p&gt;</description>

Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340649">LANG-47</key>
            <summary>test.lang fails if compiled with non iso-8859-1 locales</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="mrsam@courier-mta.org">Sam Varshavchik</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 9 Apr 2003 09:47:28 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:41:15 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:41:15 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.0</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>

                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12404006" author="bayard" created="Wed, 9 Apr 2003 21:35:18 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Alex?&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404007" author="alex@apache.org" created="Thu, 10 Apr 2003 00:33:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Fixed.  Please confirm.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In case you&apos;re interested, it was actually a problem in the test, not in the &lt;br/&gt;
code.  The test was passing in a string with non-ascii characters.  When the &lt;br/&gt;
test was compiled on a non-US/non-ASCII system, it encoded it as a different &lt;br/&gt;
char, which naturally escaped/unescaped to a different entity.  The fix was to &lt;br/&gt;
escape the funky characters explicitly in the test.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The line I changed had the following comment:&lt;br/&gt;
        // should we unicode-escape the cedilla here, for 7-bit cleanliness?&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
</comment>
                            <comment id="12404008" author="mrsam@courier-mta.org" created="Thu, 10 Apr 2003 21:27:47 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Works now in build 20030410&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>
                <customfields>
                                                                            <customfield id="customfield_12310310" key="com.atlassian.jira.toolkit:attachments">

            <title>[LANG-46] Bug in StringUtils.chomp</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-46</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The StringUtils.chomp function doesn&apos;t work.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341129">LANG-46</key>
            <summary>Bug in StringUtils.chomp</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="4">Incomplete</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="lpienia">Lionel Pieniazek</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Fri, 28 Nov 2003 03:52:43 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 16 Dec 2009 08:50:36 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 16 Dec 2009 08:50:36 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0</version>

                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12405567" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sat, 29 Nov 2003 22:01:36 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;You&apos;re going to have to do better than that if you want support &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405568" author="lpienia" created="Mon, 1 Dec 2003 00:19:20 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Sorry for the short comments, &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I have this example to show why it doesn&#194;&#180;t work.&lt;/p&gt;



&lt;p&gt;import org.apache.commons.lang.StringUtils;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public class p {&lt;br/&gt;
  public static void main(String[] args) &lt;/p&gt;
{
    String loc = &quot;es_AR&quot;;
    System.out.println(StringUtils.chomp(loc, &quot;_&quot;));
    System.out.println(StringUtils.prechomp(loc, &quot;_&quot;));
  }
&lt;p&gt;}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The result of that is:&lt;br/&gt;
es_AR&lt;br/&gt;
AR&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;when should be:&lt;br/&gt;
es&lt;br/&gt;
AR&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thanks&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405569" author="amamment" created="Tue, 2 Dec 2003 01:46:15 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Although this may not be what you expected, this behaviour is as documented in &lt;br/&gt;
the Javadocs (see below).  chomp only removes the separator from the end of &lt;br/&gt;
the string if it&apos;s there.  The proposed alternate - substringBeforeLast - may &lt;br/&gt;
do more of what you are looking for.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;-&lt;del&gt;JAVADOC CLIPPING&lt;/del&gt;-&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public static String chomp(String str,&lt;br/&gt;
                           String separator)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Removes separator from the end of str if it&apos;s there, otherwise leave it alone.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;NOTE: This method changed in version 2.0. It now more closely matches Perl &lt;br/&gt;
chomp. For the previous behavior, use substringBeforeLast(String, String). &lt;br/&gt;
This method uses String.endsWith(String).&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405570" author="lpienia" created="Tue, 2 Dec 2003 21:10:34 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Thanks!&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;There is a problem reagarding that TAGLIB String 1.0.1 that users the chomp &lt;br/&gt;
function like the older way.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;How could change that TAG to work ok?&lt;/p&gt;
</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-44] [lang] NullPointerException when passing null; not IllegalArgumentException</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-44</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;According to the JavaDoc the various methods in the Fraction class such as add()&lt;br/&gt;
throw an IllegalArgumentException when null is passed to them. This is very&lt;br/&gt;
unusual. They should throw a NullPointerException instead.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-43] [lang] SystemUtils fails init on HP-UX</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-43</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The system property for java.version is returned in HP-UX as JavaVM-1.3.0.01 &lt;br/&gt;
rather than the standard 1.3.0.01.  This causes the following Exception to be &lt;br/&gt;
thrown in SystemUtils:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;java.lang.NumberFormatException: JavV&lt;br/&gt;
at java.lang.FloatingDecimal.readJavaFormatString(Unknown Source)&lt;br/&gt;
        at java.lang.Float.parseFloat(Unknown Source)&lt;br/&gt;
        at org.apache.commons.lang.SystemUtils.getJavaVersionAsFloat&lt;br/&gt;
(SystemUtils.java:756)&lt;br/&gt;
        at org.apache.commons.lang.SystemUtils.&amp;lt;clinit&amp;gt;(SystemUtils.java:469)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The class should be modified to check if the VM is a valid number before &lt;br/&gt;
peforming the parseFloat() operation.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: HP-UX&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: HP&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341861">LANG-43</key>
            <summary>[lang] SystemUtils fails init on HP-UX</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="gritmaj@wyeth.com">Jason Gritman</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 10 Nov 2004 05:50:36 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:18:16 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:18:16 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.1</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12407997" author="gritmaj@wyeth.com" created="Wed, 10 Nov 2004 06:10:35 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I changed the following three methods to fix the issue:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    private static float getJavaVersionAsFloat() {&lt;br/&gt;
        if (JAVA_VERSION == null) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            return 0f;
        }
&lt;p&gt;        String trimmedVersion = trimJavaVersion();&lt;br/&gt;
        String str = trimmedVersion.substring(0, 3);&lt;br/&gt;
        if (trimmedVersion.length() &amp;gt;= 5) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            str = str + trimmedVersion.substring(4, 5);
        }
&lt;p&gt;        return Float.parseFloat(str);&lt;br/&gt;
    }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    private static int getJavaVersionAsInt() {&lt;br/&gt;
        if (JAVA_VERSION == null) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            return 0;
        }
&lt;p&gt;        String trimmedVersion = trimJavaVersion();&lt;br/&gt;
        String str = JAVA_VERSION.substring(0, 1);&lt;br/&gt;
        str = str + JAVA_VERSION.substring(2, 3);&lt;br/&gt;
        if (JAVA_VERSION.length() &amp;gt;= 5) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            str = str + JAVA_VERSION.substring(4, 5);
        }
&lt;p&gt; else &lt;/p&gt;
{
            str = str + &quot;0&quot;;
        }
&lt;p&gt;        return Integer.parseInt(str);&lt;br/&gt;
    }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    private static String trimJavaVersion()&lt;br/&gt;
    {&lt;br/&gt;
        if (Character.isDigit(JAVA_VERSION.charAt(0)))&lt;/p&gt;
        {
            return JAVA_VERSION.substring(
                    StringUtils.indexOf(JAVA_VERSION, &quot;0123456789&quot;));
            
        }
&lt;p&gt;        else&lt;/p&gt;
        {
            return JAVA_VERSION;
        }
&lt;p&gt;    }&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12407998" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Fri, 12 Nov 2004 08:51:26 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Added code to handle text prefixes, based on code supplied. Please retest CVS&lt;br/&gt;
code on HP-UX, as its not a platform we have ready access to &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/wink.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-42] [lang] EqualsBuilder.append(Object[], Object[]) crashes with a NullPointerException if an element of the first array is null</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-42</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;If you use EqualsBuilder.append(Object[], Object[]), and the first array contains an element that is null &lt;br/&gt;
(and before any other mismatches between the arrays are present), then EqualsBuilder will throw a &lt;br/&gt;
NullPointerException at line 513.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Steps to reproduce:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  Object[] x1 = new Object[] &lt;/p&gt;
{ new Integer(1), null, new Integer(3) }
&lt;p&gt;;&lt;br/&gt;
  Object[] x2 = new Object[] &lt;/p&gt;
{ new Integer(1), new Integer(2), new Integer(3) }
&lt;p&gt;;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  new EqualsBuilder().append(x1, x2);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The third line of this program will crash.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Attached is a patch that fixes this bug and adds code to an existing unit-test case that proves it&apos;s fixed &lt;br/&gt;
(i.e., the test fails without the source patch, and passes with it, and is a valid test).&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This patch also fixes another bug related to exact types of objects in an array (which I&apos;m about to enter, &lt;br/&gt;
and which I will relate to this bug if I figure out how &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Mac OS X 10.3&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Macintosh&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341994">LANG-42</key>
            <summary>[lang] EqualsBuilder.append(Object[], Object[]) crashes with a NullPointerException if an element of the first array is null</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="2" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/critical.svg">Critical</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
