<item>
            <title>[LANG-41] last substring returned by StringUtils.split( String, String, int ) is too long</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-41</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;My expectations for the behavior of the split( *, ..., int max ) methods don&apos;t&lt;br/&gt;
match their actual behavior.  I expected to get a maximum of &quot;max&quot; substrings,&lt;br/&gt;
all of which were delimited in the parent string by the specified delimiters. &lt;br/&gt;
Instead, what you get is &quot;max - 1&quot; such substrings, plus the rest of the parent&lt;br/&gt;
string as the final result substring.  This behavior seems counter to what&lt;br/&gt;
StringTokenizer would do, which is surprising, given the Javadoc comments about&lt;br/&gt;
using the split methods as alternatives to StringTokenizer.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341111">LANG-41</key>
            <summary>last substring returned by StringUtils.split( String, String, int ) is too long</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="hotfusionman@yahoo.com">Albert Davidson Chou</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sat, 22 Nov 2003 15:08:57 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 16 Dec 2009 08:50:41 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 16 Dec 2009 08:50:41 +0000</resolved>
                                                    <fixVersion>2.1</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12405502" author="hotfusionman@yahoo.com" created="Sat, 22 Nov 2003 15:10:07 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=9238)&lt;br/&gt;
tests to demonstrate desired behavior and patch to implement it&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405503" author="hotfusionman@yahoo.com" created="Sun, 23 Nov 2003 06:55:17 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Most likely my zipped patch files won&apos;t be readable.  That&apos;s just as well, given&lt;br/&gt;
that they patch the current contents of CVS rather than the state I would expect&lt;br/&gt;
to exist if my patch for &lt;a href=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-41&quot; title=&quot;last substring returned by StringUtils.split( String, String, int ) is too long&quot; class=&quot;issue-link&quot; data-issue-key=&quot;LANG-41&quot;&gt;&lt;del&gt;COM-960&lt;/del&gt;&lt;/a&gt; is committed.  I&apos;ll re-diff and resubmit a&lt;br/&gt;
patch if/when that&apos;s desired.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405504" author="phil@steitz.com" created="Sun, 23 Nov 2003 07:52:49 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I don&apos;t understand what the problem is.  The following tests (taken from your&lt;br/&gt;
patch, eliminating the added boolean parameter) succeed with the current code:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;String stringToSplitOnNulls = &quot;ab   de fg&quot; ;&lt;br/&gt;
        String[] splitOnNullExpectedResults = &lt;/p&gt;
{ &quot;ab&quot;, &quot;de&quot;, &quot;fg&quot; }
&lt;p&gt;;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        String[] splitOnNullResults = StringUtils.split( &quot;ab   de fg&quot;, null);&lt;br/&gt;
        assertEquals(splitOnNullExpectedResults.length, splitOnNullResults.length);&lt;br/&gt;
        for (int i = 0 ; i &amp;lt; splitOnNullExpectedResults.length ; i+= 1) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            assertEquals(splitOnNullExpectedResults[i], splitOnNullResults[i]);
        }

&lt;p&gt;        String[] expectedResults = &lt;/p&gt;
{ &quot;ab&quot;, &quot;de fg&quot; }
&lt;p&gt;;&lt;br/&gt;
        splitOnNullResults = StringUtils.split( &quot;ab   de fg&quot;, null, 2);&lt;br/&gt;
        assertEquals(expectedResults.length, splitOnNullResults.length);&lt;br/&gt;
        for ( int i = 0 ; i &amp;lt; expectedResults.length ; i+= 1 ) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            assertEquals(expectedResults[i], splitOnNullResults[i]);
        }

&lt;p&gt;Looks to me like the current code is functioning as advertised. See the example&lt;br/&gt;
in the javadoc:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;StringUtils.split(&quot;ab:cd:ef&quot;, &quot;:&quot;, 2)    = &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;&amp;quot;ab&amp;quot;, &amp;quot;cdef&amp;quot;&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Probably should add your example, which shows that in the case of a whitspace&lt;br/&gt;
delimiter, the delimiter is not stripped from the terminal segment.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I would not support changing this behavior, since this would change the&lt;br/&gt;
contract.  It might be a good idea, however, to drop the javadoc reference to&lt;br/&gt;
the StringTokenizer.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405505" author="hotfusionman@yahoo.com" created="Sun, 23 Nov 2003 15:42:19 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Sorry, the patch was too big to easily pinpoint the changes to the tests that&lt;br/&gt;
demonstrate my desired behavior for the existing methods.  They&apos;re actually in&lt;br/&gt;
innerTestSplit():&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;ul class=&quot;alternate&quot; type=&quot;square&quot;&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;assertEquals(msg, str, res&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;0&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;);&lt;br/&gt;
+        assertEquals(msg, &quot;a&quot;, res&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;0&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;);&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;ul class=&quot;alternate&quot; type=&quot;square&quot;&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;assertEquals(msg, str.substring(2), res&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;);&lt;br/&gt;
+        assertEquals(msg, &quot;b&quot;, res&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;1&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;);&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;I agree the above is a change to the contract of these methods; I wanted to&lt;br/&gt;
raise the question as to whether the existing contract is the most&lt;br/&gt;
useful/sensible one.  It sure surprised me that the last substring returned by&lt;br/&gt;
the method had different properties from the others.  It doesn&apos;t make sense to&lt;br/&gt;
me, but maybe it does to other people.  If so, that&apos;s fine.&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;Furthermore, the Javadoc example&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;StringUtils.split(&quot;ab:cd:ef&quot;, &quot;:&quot;, 2)    = &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;&amp;quot;ab&amp;quot;, &amp;quot;cdef&amp;quot;&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;should read&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;StringUtils.split(&quot;ab:cd:ef&quot;, &quot;:&quot;, 2)    = &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;&amp;quot;ab&amp;quot;, &amp;quot;cd:ef&amp;quot;&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;in order to reflect what the code currently does (what it does is in some sense&lt;br/&gt;
sensible, though not what I would expect).  What the Javadoc says is just plain&lt;br/&gt;
weird, but I assume it was a typo.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405506" author="phil@steitz.com" created="Mon, 24 Nov 2003 04:46:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;You are correct.  There was an error in the javadoc.  I have fixed the error and&lt;br/&gt;
added test cases to verify current behavior.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405507" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sat, 29 Nov 2003 22:00:51 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Closing this for now, as the javadoc has been fixed&lt;/p&gt;</comment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-40] [lang] Validate.noNullEmelents(Object[], String) does not use message if Object[] == null</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-40</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The first statement in Validate.noNullEmelents(Object[], String) is &lt;br/&gt;
Validate.notNull(array). This should be Validate.notNull(array, message). &lt;br/&gt;
Because of this, the message is not used when the array is null itself. This &lt;br/&gt;
also applies to Validate.noNullEmelents(Collection, String).&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Linux&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341462">LANG-40</key>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-38] [lang] Rationalize StringUtils slice functions</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-38</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The attached patch modifies the behavior of StringUtils.sliceFirst and&lt;br/&gt;
StringUtils.sliceFirstRemainder to consistently handle &amp;lt;string, delimiter&amp;gt; pairs&lt;br/&gt;
where the delimiter is null, empty or does not occur in the string, as discussed&lt;br/&gt;
on the list.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The patch also refactors the slice functions to take advantage of&lt;br/&gt;
StringUtils.indexOf and StringUtils.lastIndexOf.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340871">LANG-38</key>
            <summary>[lang] Rationalize StringUtils slice functions</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-37] [lang] unit test for org.apache.commons.lang.text.StrBuilder</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-37</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Gary Gregory wrote:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I hate to put a damper on things so late in the game but Clover reports&lt;br/&gt;
that we have 0% code coverage for three new 2.1 classes&lt;br/&gt;
(MappedMessageFormat, StrBuilder, StrTokenizer.StringMatcher) in the new&lt;br/&gt;
to 2.1 package:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://people.apache.org/~stevencaswell/commons-lang-2.1/docs/clover/org&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://people.apache.org/~stevencaswell/commons-lang-2.1/docs/clover/org&lt;/a&gt;&lt;br/&gt;
/apache/commons/lang/text/pkg-summary.html&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Sadly, this makes the coverage for this new package the lowest % in all&lt;br/&gt;
of &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;lang&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Did someone forget to commit unit tests? This surely must be an omission&lt;br/&gt;
of some kind. I cannot see us releasing without unit tests for this new&lt;br/&gt;
code.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Gary&lt;/p&gt;


&lt;p&gt;Attached is the start of a unit test for StrBuilder.  Sorry it is not complete &amp;#8211; I ran out of steam.&lt;/p&gt;</description>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-36] [lang] patch and test case fixing problem with RandomStringUtils.random()</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-36</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;When a set of characters is supplied to RandomStringUtils.random(), the last&lt;br/&gt;
character in the set never appears in generated strings.  &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Attaching patch and test case showing failure.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The test case generates 100 6-character strings from a 3-character set and&lt;br/&gt;
compares the observed frequency of occurrence of each of the characters in the&lt;br/&gt;
set with expectation assuming purely random selection.  Uses a chi-square test.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340707">LANG-36</key>
            <summary>[lang] patch and test case fixing problem with RandomStringUtils.random()</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-35</link>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-34] [lang] Add support in ToStringStyle for DateFormat.</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-34</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;This stems from a discussion on commons-user.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The basic idea is that ToStringStyle could be customized to include an optional&lt;br/&gt;
java.text DataFormat object. If the attched patch were in (mod some formatting&lt;br/&gt;
and unit tests which I can do), user could write code like this:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;import java.lang.reflect.Field;&lt;br/&gt;
import java.text.SimpleDateFormat;&lt;br/&gt;
import java.util.Date;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;import org.apache.commons.lang.builder.ReflectionToStringBuilder;&lt;br/&gt;
import org.apache.commons.lang.builder.ToStringStyle;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;public class TestRTSB {&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    static class MyToStringStyle extends ToStringStyle {&lt;br/&gt;
        MyToStringStyle() &lt;/p&gt;
{
            this.setDateFormat(new SimpleDateFormat(&quot;yyyy-MM-dd&quot;));
        }
&lt;p&gt;    }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    public static void main(String[] arguments) &lt;/p&gt;
{
        System.out.println(new TestRTSB());
    }

&lt;p&gt;    private int foo = 22;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    private Date myDate = new Date();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    public String toString() &lt;/p&gt;
{
        return new ReflectionToStringBuilder(this, new
MyToStringStyle()).toString();
    }

&lt;p&gt;// Use ToStringStyle.setDateFormat instead of:&lt;br/&gt;
//&lt;br/&gt;
//    public String toString0() {&lt;br/&gt;
//        return (new ReflectionToStringBuilder(this) {&lt;br/&gt;
//            protected Object getValue(Field field) throws&lt;br/&gt;
IllegalArgumentException, IllegalAccessException {&lt;br/&gt;
//                Object value = super.getValue(field);&lt;br/&gt;
//                if (&quot;myDate&quot;.equals(field.getName())) &lt;/p&gt;
{
//                    return new SimpleDateFormat(&quot;yyyy-MM-dd&quot;).format(value);
//                }
&lt;p&gt; else &lt;/p&gt;
{
//                    return value;
//                }
&lt;p&gt;//            }&lt;br/&gt;
//        }).toString();&lt;br/&gt;
//    }&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Any thoughts?&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340854">LANG-34</key>
            <summary>[lang] Add support in ToStringStyle for DateFormat.</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="ggregory">Gary D. Gregory</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Thu, 17 Jul 2003 01:48:16 +0000</created>
                <updated>Thu, 10 Mar 2011 22:30:46 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:37:49 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>1.0.1</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.1</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12404706" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Thu, 17 Jul 2003 01:50:58 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=7332)&lt;br/&gt;
ToStringBuilder.java&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404707" author="bbuckley" created="Thu, 17 Jul 2003 14:45:28 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Rather than adding support for just java.util.Date, consider adding support to &lt;br/&gt;
allow a user to custom format any type of field.  Something like this:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;1. Create an interface called say ToStringer&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    public class ToStringer&lt;/p&gt;
{
          String toString(Object objectToFormat);
    }

&lt;p&gt;2. Add a method to ToStringStyle called say addToStringer to add custom &lt;br/&gt;
formatters for specific field types.  Add a map field to hold the formatters.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    public void addToStringer(Class type, ToStringer formatter)&lt;/p&gt;
{
       formatters.put(type,formatter);
    }

&lt;p&gt;3. Then a client will use/configure ToStringStyle like this to custom format &lt;br/&gt;
say fields of type Dates, Doubles and Foos:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        ToStringStyle t = new ToStringStyle();&lt;br/&gt;
        t.addToStringer(java.util.Date.class,new ToStringer(){&lt;br/&gt;
            String toString(Object date)&lt;/p&gt;
{
                Date d = (Date date);
                return new SimpleDateFormat(&quot;yyyy-MM-dd&quot;).format(d);
            }
&lt;p&gt;        });&lt;br/&gt;
        t.addToStringer(Double.class,new ToStringer(){&lt;br/&gt;
              String toString(Object decimal)&lt;/p&gt;
{
                  return new DecimalFormat(&quot;#,000.0000&quot;).format(decimal);
              }
&lt;p&gt;          });&lt;br/&gt;
        t.addToStringer(Foo.class,new ToStringer(){&lt;br/&gt;
              String toString(Object foo)&lt;/p&gt;
{
                  Foo f = (Foo)foo;
                  return &quot;Foo object #&quot; + f.getId();
              }
&lt;p&gt;          });&lt;br/&gt;
        }&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;-Brian&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404708" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Fri, 18 Jul 2003 00:01:38 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;If we do something like that the interface function could also be (presumably&lt;br/&gt;
for internal efficiency):&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;append(Object object, StringBuffer buffer);&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;We can discuss the 3 approaches and see what people think.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404709" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Tue, 22 Jul 2003 06:45:12 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;A full converter approach is the right one if a change is to be made.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This should wait until after 2.0 though.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404710" author="bayard" created="Sun, 27 Jun 2004 11:21:47 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Dropping this from 2.1 aims. Commons-Convert does seem the better choice if&lt;br/&gt;
people want this to be of a lot of use.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404711" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sun, 17 Oct 2004 01:25:53 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I have added some javadoc to ToStringStyle to demonstrate how to format fields.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The rest of this goes beyond lang at the moment into the realms of convert and &lt;br/&gt;
the text package. The idea is not invalid though, so it may yet come back.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12404712" author="bayard" created="Wed, 26 Apr 2006 13:10:49 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;2.1 released, closing.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                            <attachment id="12332414" name="ASF.LICENSE.NOT.GRANTED--patch.txt" size="32996" author="ggregory@seagullsw.com" created="Thu, 17 Jul 2003 01:50:58 +0000"/>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>
                <customfields>
                                                                            <customfield id="customfield_12310310" key="com.atlassian.jira.toolkit:attachments">
                        <customfieldname>Attachment count</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>1.0</customfieldvalue>
                        </customfieldvalues>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-33] Method enums.Enum.equals(Object o) doesn&apos;t work correctly.</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-33</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;equals considers self equal to any Object that has an accessible public getName&lt;br/&gt;
() method which returns a string that is the same than the internal name iName. &lt;br/&gt;
So if you compare two objects of subclasses of Enum that are not related &lt;br/&gt;
otherwise, but incidentally have the same name iName the equals method returns &lt;br/&gt;
true. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;But even worse, it&apos;s also possible to compare a subclass of Enum to an object &lt;br/&gt;
of a totally unrelated class and to consider the objects equal if the totally &lt;br/&gt;
unrelated class provides a getName method that returns a string equal to iName. &lt;br/&gt;
If the getName method of the other object isn&apos;t accessible, an &lt;br/&gt;
IllegalAccessException is thrown and caught in the equals method and false is &lt;br/&gt;
returned which in this case seems to be correct.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The root of the problem is the use of reflection without checking first whether &lt;br/&gt;
the names of the classes (via other.getClass().getName().equals(this.getClass&lt;br/&gt;
().getName())) are the same (not the classes themselves, this is tested by the &lt;br/&gt;
equals method) before invoking the getName method on the other object via &lt;br/&gt;
reflection. If the names of the classes aren&apos;t equal, false can be returned &lt;br/&gt;
immediately instead of using reflection. Only if the classnames are equal &lt;br/&gt;
reflection should be used to determine equality.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Note: The old implementation of Enums.equals in the commons-lang 2.0 &lt;br/&gt;
distribution seems to work ok in the first case with both objects being &lt;br/&gt;
subclasses of Enum. In the second case of the totally unrelated class, a &lt;br/&gt;
ClassCastException is thrown, but according to Joshua Bloch (Effective Java) &lt;br/&gt;
and the SDK-API-Documentation for Object.equals this violates the contract for &lt;br/&gt;
equals because equals is supposed to deliver true or false for any two non null &lt;br/&gt;
references.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341384">LANG-33</key>
            <summary>Method enums.Enum.equals(Object o) doesn&apos;t work correctly.</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="demitsch@freenet.de">Matthias Eichel</reporter>

                            <comment id="12406395" author="demitsch@freenet.de" created="Sun, 4 Apr 2004 05:10:12 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Created an attachment (id=11117)&lt;br/&gt;

<item>
            <title>[LANG-32] [lang] Error in JavaDoc for StringUtils.chomp(String, String)</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-32</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;There&apos;s an error in the JavaDoc for the StringUtils.chomp(String, String)&lt;br/&gt;
method. One of the examples says:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;StringUtils.chomp(&quot;foo &quot;, &quot;foo&quot;) = &quot;foo&quot;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This should be:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;StringUtils.chomp(&quot;foo &quot;, &quot;foo&quot;)   = &quot;foo &quot;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-30] [lang] buffer under/overrun on Strings.strip, stripStart &amp; stripEnd</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-30</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Example:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;   stripStart(&quot;   &quot;, null); &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;fails with a buffer overrun.   Here&apos;s a patch:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;&amp;#8212; Strings.java	Mon May 27 00:41:41 2002&lt;br/&gt;
+++ Strings.java.patched	Mon May 27 00:41:51 2002&lt;br/&gt;
@@ -1151,16 +1151,16 @@&lt;br/&gt;
         int end = str.length();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;         if(ch == null) {&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul class=&quot;alternate&quot; type=&quot;square&quot;&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;while( Character.isWhitespace( str.charAt(end-1) ) ) 
&lt;div class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;Unknown macro: {+            while( end &amp;gt; 0 &amp;amp;&amp;amp; Character.isWhitespace( str.charAt(end-1) ) ) {
                 end--;
             }&lt;br/&gt;
         } else {&lt;br/&gt;
             char chr = ch.charAt(0);&lt;br/&gt;
-            while( str.charAt(end-1) == chr ) {&lt;br/&gt;
+            while( end &amp;gt; 0 &amp;amp;&amp;amp; str.charAt(end-1) == chr ) {                 end--;             }         }&lt;/span&gt; &lt;/div&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;return str.substring(0, end);&lt;br/&gt;
+        return (end &amp;gt; 0) ? str.substring(0, end) : &quot;&quot;;&lt;br/&gt;
     }&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;     /**&lt;br/&gt;
@@ -1168,18 +1168,19 @@&lt;br/&gt;
      */&lt;br/&gt;
     static public String stripStart(String str, String ch) {&lt;br/&gt;
         int start = 0;&lt;br/&gt;
+        int end = str.length();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;         if(ch == null) {&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul class=&quot;alternate&quot; type=&quot;square&quot;&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;while( Character.isWhitespace( str.charAt(start) ) ) 
&lt;div class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;Unknown macro: {+            while( start &amp;lt; end &amp;amp;&amp;amp; Character.isWhitespace( str.charAt(start) ) ) {
                 start++;
             }&lt;br/&gt;
         } else {&lt;br/&gt;
             char chr = ch.charAt(0);&lt;br/&gt;
-            while( str.charAt(start) == chr ) {&lt;br/&gt;
+            while( start &amp;lt; end &amp;amp;&amp;amp; str.charAt(start) == chr ) {                 start++;             }         }&lt;/span&gt; &lt;/div&gt;&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;return str.substring(start);&lt;br/&gt;
+        return (start &amp;lt; end) ? str.substring(start) : &quot;&quot;;&lt;br/&gt;
     }&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;     /**&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340232">LANG-30</key>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-29] [lang] Fraction compareTo is inconsistent with equals</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-29</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The ordering of the compareTo method method in the Fraction class is&lt;br/&gt;
inconsistent with equals() because 1/2 is not equal to 2/4. However&lt;br/&gt;
1/2.compareTo(2/4) is 0. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;My gut feeling is that the equals method is broken and should be fixed. 1/2 ==&lt;br/&gt;
2/4. However if there are good reasons for keeping the current behavior, then at&lt;br/&gt;
a minimum the inconsistency shoudl be called out in the JavaDoc, and users&lt;br/&gt;
should be warned against using fractions in hash tables and sorted maps and the&lt;br/&gt;
like. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;For background see &lt;a href=&quot;http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.3/docs/api/java/lang/Comparable.html&quot; class=&quot;external-link&quot; rel=&quot;nofollow&quot;&gt;http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.3/docs/api/java/lang/Comparable.html&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342535">LANG-29</key>
            <summary>[lang] Fraction compareTo is inconsistent with equals</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="elharo@metalab.unc.edu">elharo</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 7 Sep 2005 06:13:17 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 6 Feb 2007 23:47:10 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 6 Feb 2007 23:47:10 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.1</version>
                                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12410353" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Wed, 7 Sep 2005 06:59:51 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;This is correct behaviour for this class.&lt;br/&gt;
The commons-lang Fraction class represents a general purpose fraction&lt;br/&gt;
implementation where fractions such as 2/4 may be stored. Equals thus performs&lt;br/&gt;
correctly and treats 1/2 and 2/4 as different as they have different state.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;For an alternative Fraction implementation see commons-math (upcoming v1.1?).&lt;br/&gt;
There the fraction is always reduced, and may be more in line with a&lt;br/&gt;
mathematicians thought processes.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Extra javadoc added to compareTo in line with Comparable.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12410354" author="elharo@metalab.unc.edu" created="Wed, 7 Sep 2005 07:19:11 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The fact that the internal state is different does not in itself imply that the&lt;br/&gt;
equals() method should return false. Two objects with different field values can&lt;br/&gt;
be considered equal. There&apos;s nothing in the contract for equality that says two&lt;br/&gt;
equal objects must have bit-per-bit identical representations.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Here I think there are two strong reasons to make 1/2.equals(2/4). The first is&lt;br/&gt;
the obvious natural mathemtical reason. Users naturally expect that 1/2 equals 2/4.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The second is the consistency with compareTo. Breaking this shouldn&apos;t be done&lt;br/&gt;
without a really good reason. Is there such a reason? i.e. is there some use&lt;br/&gt;
case that depends on 1/2 != 2/4? If not, or if the use case is not compelling&lt;br/&gt;
enough, I think we shoudl consider revising the behavior of the equals() method.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If there is such a use-case, then we need to consider revising the behavior of&lt;br/&gt;
the compareTo() method to make it consistent. Perhaps we could consistently&lt;br/&gt;
resolve conflicts based on the size of the denominator. For instance, 3/6 &amp;gt; 2/4&lt;br/&gt;
&amp;gt; 1/2. However, that&apos;s pretty weird and I&apos;d really prefer to fix equals instead.&lt;br/&gt;
 (Plus something&apos;s tickling the back of my brain, saying there&apos;s some deep&lt;br/&gt;
mathematical reason that scheme isn&apos;t going to work. I&apos;ll have to pull out my&lt;br/&gt;
old number theory books and look up well-ordering.)&lt;/p&gt;

</comment>
                            <comment id="12410355" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Sat, 10 Sep 2005 18:52:46 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;There are cases in the JDK where compareTo and equals do not match. eg.&lt;br/&gt;
BigDecimal, where 1.000 != 1.0, but they compareTo to 0. And whats more (in&lt;br/&gt;
JDK1.4 at least) they don&apos;t use the correct wording from Comparable.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;And yes, in my opinion, equals does represent a comparison on state. (This is&lt;br/&gt;
really a discussion about the weaknesses in some core JDK definitions.)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Use case wise, it is perfectly reasonable for someone to want to store a&lt;br/&gt;
fraction of the form 2/4. This may have a particular meaning in an engineering&lt;br/&gt;
or teaching domain for example. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If you want reduced fractions, simply use the dedicated factory method, or call&lt;br/&gt;
te reduce method before using equals.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Finally, backwards compatability really does mean we can&apos;t fix this. Lang has&lt;br/&gt;
high standards on compatability, and this would be a clear semantic break.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12410356" author="elharo@metalab.unc.edu" created="Fri, 11 Nov 2005 00:09:19 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I didn&apos;t mean a use case where one should store 2/4. I accept that there are&lt;br/&gt;
such use cases. I was asking for a use case where one would want 1/2 and 2/4 to&lt;br/&gt;
compare unequal. Barring such a use case, I might believe that backwards&lt;br/&gt;
compatibility prevents you from fixing this bug, but I still maintain it&apos;s a bug. &lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12410357" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Fri, 11 Nov 2005 08:12:31 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;In coding 1/2 not equal to 2/4, I believe that we followed established JDK&lt;br/&gt;
practice of equals() representing state.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;My use case is that two objects that are equal() should be capable of being&lt;br/&gt;
swapped in a program with no adverse effects on subsequent code. In this case&lt;br/&gt;
swapping 2/4 with 1/2 could definitely affect subsequent code.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;As I said before, there is more than one possible contract for equals, and so we&lt;br/&gt;
chose one.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>

            <title>[LANG-27] [lang] Add SystemUtils.AWT_TOOLKIT and others.</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-27</link>

                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Add SystemUtils.AWT_TOOLKIT, which is useful to detect whether or not the JRE is&lt;br/&gt;
running on a headless platform.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;

        <key id="12341260">LANG-27</key>
            <summary>[lang] Add SystemUtils.AWT_TOOLKIT and others.</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-25] [lang] DurationFormatUtils.formatDurationISO() javadoc is missing T in duration string between date and time part</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-25</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The javadoc says: &quot;This method formats durations using the days and lower fields&lt;br/&gt;
of the ISO format pattern, such as P7D6H5M4.321S.&quot; the example duration is&lt;br/&gt;
missing a T between the date part 7D and the time part 6H5M4.321S. The format is&lt;br/&gt;
P1M for 1 month and PT1M for one minute.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-24] [lang] DateUtils.truncate oddity at the far end of the Date spectrum</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-24</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;I&apos;m assuming that the goal of the truncate() method in&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.lang.time.DateUtils is to be a shorthand for the otherwise&lt;br/&gt;
cumbersome java.util.Calendar operations of setting all lower fields to 0.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;In other words, the following 2 methods are (by me) expected to yield the same:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    private Date commonsTruncate(Date date)&lt;/p&gt;
    {
        return DateUtils.truncate(date, Calendar.DATE);
    }

&lt;p&gt;    private Date truncate(Date date)&lt;/p&gt;
    {
        Calendar c = Calendar.getInstance();
        c.setTime(date);
        c.set(Calendar.HOUR_OF_DAY, 0);
        c.set(Calendar.MINUTE, 0);
        c.set(Calendar.SECOND, 0);
        c.set(Calendar.MILLISECOND, 0);
        return c.getTime();
    }

&lt;p&gt;This is generally the case, except for the very pathological case of the&lt;br/&gt;
ultimate biggest date Java allows you to make:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    Date endOfTime = new Date(Long.MAX_VALUE); &lt;br/&gt;
    // fyi: Sun Aug 17 07:12:55 CET 292278994 &amp;#8211; 807 millis&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;commons-result:  Sun Aug 17 02:00:00 CEST 292278994 &lt;br/&gt;
                 // commonsTruncate(endOfTime)&lt;br/&gt;
handmade-result: Sun Aug 17 00:00:00 CEST 292278994 &lt;br/&gt;
                 // truncate(endOfTime)&lt;br/&gt;
(mind the 2h difference)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Another odd observation concerning this special date is that the commons-result&lt;br/&gt;
WILL match the other one if we allow the commons truncate to operate on the&lt;br/&gt;
result again:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;commons-double-truncate-result: &lt;br/&gt;
                 Sun Aug 17 00:00:00 CEST 292278994   &lt;br/&gt;
                 // truncate(truncate(endOfTime))&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;(which is somewhat another surprise: one would expect truncation not to change a&lt;br/&gt;
Date that was already truncated)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;my (totally wild) guess is that this is related to timezone and DST issues&lt;br/&gt;
fact being that similar effects are seen on all Date&apos;s pointing to a moment in&lt;br/&gt;
the last 2hours of the Date spectrum.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I understand that this is a very hypothetical issue, nevertheless.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;kind regards,&lt;br/&gt;
-marc=&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341747">LANG-24</key>
            <summary>[lang] DateUtils.truncate oddity at the far end of the Date spectrum</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="4" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/minor.svg">Minor</priority>

            <title>[LANG-23] [lang] String StringUtils.leftPad(String str, int size, char padChar) NoSuchMethodError</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-23</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;When I use StringUtils.leftPad(String str, int size, char padChar) I get an Error:&lt;br/&gt;

org.apache.commons.lang.StringUtils.leftPad(Ljava/lang/String;IC)Ljava/lang/String;&lt;/p&gt;

String a = StringUtils.leftPad(&quot;abcd&quot;, 10, &apos;0&apos;);&lt;/p&gt;</description>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-22] [lang] Enum.equals() is too fragile</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-22</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The equals() method of the Enum class in Commons Lang 2.0 is too fragile.  If&lt;br/&gt;
the &quot;Other&quot; argument is a non-null abject of any other type than Enum, then a&lt;br/&gt;
ClassCastException is thrown.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The offending line code is:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;  if (other == this) &lt;/p&gt;
{
    return true;
  }
&lt;p&gt; else if (other == null) &lt;/p&gt;
{
    return false;
  }
&lt;p&gt; else if (other.getClass() == this.getClass()) &lt;/p&gt;
{
    // shouldn&apos;t happen, but...
    return iName.equals(((Enum) other).iName);
  }
&lt;p&gt; else if (((Enum)&lt;br/&gt;
other).getEnumClass().getName().equals(getEnumClass().getName())) {&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If &quot;other&quot; is, say, a String, then the last else-if clause will throw an&lt;br/&gt;
exception when it tries to cast it to Enum.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;This method should be more robust, and tolerate ANY argument, regardless of type.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12342207">LANG-22</key>
            <summary>[lang] Enum.equals() is too fragile</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-21] [lang] escapeXML() -&gt; Not escaping low characters</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-21</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Low characters such as #18 are not escaped, and therefore are mixed together &lt;br/&gt;
with other characteres as if there were normal characteres such as &apos;a&apos;, &apos;1&apos; etc.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Possibly solved in other versions?&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12343003">LANG-21</key>
            <summary>[lang] escapeXML() -&gt; Not escaping low characters</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="2">Won&apos;t Fix</resolution>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-20] Infinite loop in ToStringBuilder.reflectionToString for inner classes</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-20</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;ToStringBuilder.reflectionToString() enters an infinite loop when used with the &lt;br/&gt;
following example:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;/////////////////////////////&lt;br/&gt;
public class Outer {&lt;br/&gt;
  Inner inner = new Inner();&lt;br/&gt;
  class Inner {&lt;br/&gt;
    public String toString() &lt;/p&gt;
{
      return ToStringBuilder.reflectionToString(this);
    }
&lt;p&gt;  }&lt;br/&gt;
  public String toString() &lt;/p&gt;
{
    return ToStringBuilder.reflectionToString(this);
  }
&lt;p&gt;  public static void main(String[] args) &lt;/p&gt;
{
    Outer outer = new Outer();
    System.out.println(outer);
  }
&lt;p&gt;}&lt;br/&gt;
/////////////////////////////&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The reason is that the two classes refer to each other via the explicit field &lt;br/&gt;
inner and the implicit field Outer.this. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;The bug can be resolved by skipping the implicit fields. Is there any good &lt;br/&gt;
reason for printing those anyway?&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I am not sure what is the best way to detect if a field is an implicit field. &lt;br/&gt;
But I patched the code myself in a way that seemed to work:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;/////////////////////////////&lt;br/&gt;
public static String reflectionToString(Object object, ToStringStyle style, &lt;br/&gt;
        boolean outputTransients) {&lt;br/&gt;
    if (object == null) &lt;/p&gt;
{
        throw new IllegalArgumentException(&quot;The object must not be null&quot;);
    }
&lt;p&gt;    if (style == null) &lt;/p&gt;
{
        style = getDefaultStyle();
    }
&lt;p&gt;    Field[] fields = object.getClass().getDeclaredFields();&lt;br/&gt;
    Field.setAccessible(fields, true);&lt;br/&gt;
    ToStringBuilder builder = new ToStringBuilder(object, style);&lt;br/&gt;
    for (int i = 0; i &amp;lt; fields.length; ++i) {&lt;br/&gt;
        Field f = fields&lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;i&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt;;&lt;br/&gt;
        if (!f.getName().startsWith(&quot;this$&quot;)) {&lt;br/&gt;
          if (outputTransients || !Modifier.isTransient(f.getModifiers())) {&lt;br/&gt;
              if (!Modifier.isStatic(f.getModifiers())) {&lt;br/&gt;
                  try &lt;/p&gt;
{
                      builder.append(f.getName(), f.get(object));
                      
                  }
&lt;p&gt; catch (IllegalAccessException ex) &lt;/p&gt;
{
                      //this can&apos;t happen. Would get a Security exception 
instead
                      //throw a runtime exception in case the impossible 
happens.
                      throw new InternalError(&quot;Unexpected 
IllegalAccessException&quot;);
                  }
&lt;p&gt;              }&lt;br/&gt;
          }&lt;br/&gt;
        }&lt;br/&gt;
    }&lt;br/&gt;
    return builder.toString();&lt;br/&gt;
}&lt;br/&gt;
/////////////////////////////&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Notice the extra if statement that tests for field names starting with &quot;this$&quot;. &lt;br/&gt;
I don&apos;t know if this is guaranteed to work always, though.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340483">LANG-20</key>
            <summary>Infinite loop in ToStringBuilder.reflectionToString for inner classes</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/blocker.svg">Blocker</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="per@velschow.com">Per Velschow</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Sat, 11 Jan 2003 13:27:37 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:44:16 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:44:16 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.0</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12403426" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Mon, 20 Jan 2003 02:51:15 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Change made which should deal with this situation.&lt;br/&gt;
Thanks for the report and test.&lt;br/&gt;
Stephen&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12403427" author="per@velschow.com" created="Mon, 20 Jan 2003 03:10:04 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I just checked the changes in CVS. If I read the code correctly, it will now &lt;br/&gt;
discard any field name containing a &apos;$&apos; character. This may be too restrictive &lt;br/&gt;
since &apos;$&apos; is a legal identifier part AFAIK.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Also, I have thought a bit more about the problem. It is actually a more &lt;br/&gt;
general problem than the one I reported. Inner classes are not the only way you &lt;br/&gt;
could have mutually recursive data structures. So perhaps we should think of a &lt;br/&gt;
more general way of preventing this infinite loop. I have not made any solution &lt;br/&gt;
yet, but I think it might be solved using a Set of references to already &lt;br/&gt;
traversed instances and then avoid traversing an instance if it has already &lt;br/&gt;
been traversed.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>

                            <customfieldvalue>Mon, 20 Jan 2003 02:51:15 +0000</customfieldvalue>

                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                <customfield id="customfield_12314020" key="com.atlassian.jira.plugins.jira-development-integration-plugin:devsummary">

                    </customfield>

                        <customfieldname>Enable Automatic Patch Review</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue><![CDATA[false]]></customfieldvalue>

                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                <customfield id="customfield_12310420" key="com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-global-rank">
                        <customfieldname>Global Rank</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>34102</customfieldvalue>
                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>

                        <customfieldvalues>
                            18 years, 25 weeks, 2 days ago
                        </customfieldvalues>

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        <customfield id="customfield_12311820" key="com.pyxis.greenhopper.jira:gh-lexo-rank">

                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>0|i0d79r:</customfieldvalue>

                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>

                        <customfieldname>Rank (Obsolete)</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>74954</customfieldvalue>
                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-19] [lang] ToStringStyle.setArrayEnd(String) doesn&apos;t replace null with empty string.</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-19</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;According to the javadoc of the ToStringStyle.setArrayEnd(String) method,  &lt;br/&gt;
null is accepted, but will be converted to an empty String.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;But, in actual this method does not convert null.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;attached are a fix and a junit test.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341837">LANG-19</key>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-18] [lang] BitSetUtils class, toIndexArray and fromIndexArray</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-18</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Attached is a new clas BitSetUtils, with methods&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;/**&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Return an int array of the indicies of set bits in the&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;specified bit set.&lt;br/&gt;
 *&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@param bitSet bit set, must not be null&lt;br/&gt;
 */&lt;br/&gt;
public static final int[] toIndexArray(final BitSet bitSet)&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;and&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;/**&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;Return a bit set of the specified size with the indices specified&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;in &amp;lt;code&amp;gt;indexArray&amp;lt;/code&amp;gt; set to true.&lt;br/&gt;
 *&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@param size initial size of the bit set&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;@param indexArray array of indices to set to true, must not be null&lt;br/&gt;
 */&lt;br/&gt;
public static final BitSet fromIndexArray(final int size,&lt;br/&gt;
                                          final int[] indexArray)&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;for possible inclusion in &lt;span class=&quot;error&quot;&gt;&amp;#91;collections&amp;#93;&lt;/span&gt; post-3.0-release&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341219">LANG-18</key>
            <summary>[lang] BitSetUtils class, toIndexArray and fromIndexArray</summary>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-16] NumberRange inaccurate for Long, etc.</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-16</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;NumberRange assumes everything is representable by a double. This is not the&lt;br/&gt;
case. In particular the classes Long, BigInteger and BigDecimal are standard&lt;br/&gt;
parts of J2SE that do not obey to assumption. As an example the following test&lt;br/&gt;
fails.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        assertFalse(new NumberRange(new Long(Long.MAX_VALUE)).includesNumber(new&lt;br/&gt;
Long(Long.MAX_VALUE-1)));&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I guess this bug is really a problem with the design of the class. You could&lt;br/&gt;
check the exact class and take appropriate action, but that would be long,&lt;br/&gt;
complicated and quite possibly pointless. I would suggest that the class is&lt;br/&gt;
replaced with one that assumes doubles instead of Number.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340435">LANG-16</key>
            <summary>NumberRange inaccurate for Long, etc.</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="tackline@tackline.demon.co.uk">Thomas Hawtin</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Wed, 27 Nov 2002 15:30:33 +0000</created>
                <updated>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:45:06 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Tue, 16 May 2006 12:45:06 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.0</fixVersion>
                                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12403275" author="scolebourne@joda.org" created="Mon, 23 Dec 2002 07:21:53 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;I agree with you. The NumberRange class is broken. &lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I have commented the original as being broken, and created a subpackage of math &lt;br/&gt;
with specific range implementations for Number, and primitive types.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Check it out and see if it meets your requirements.&lt;br/&gt;
Stephen&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>
                <subtasks>
                    </subtasks>
                <customfields>
                                                                            <customfield id="customfield_12310310" key="com.atlassian.jira.toolkit:attachments">
                        <customfieldname>Attachment count</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>0.0</customfieldvalue>
                        </customfieldvalues>
                    </customfield>
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        <customfield id="customfield_10010" key="com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.customfieldtypes:importid">
                        <customfieldname>Bugzilla Id</customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalues>
                            <customfieldvalue>14884</customfieldvalue>
                        </customfieldvalues>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-15] Infinite loop in StringUtils.replace(text, repl, with) + FIX</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-15</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Hopefully I can give back a little after having had so much&lt;br/&gt;
benefit of your work.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I will refer to the sources from commons-lang-1.0.1-src.zip, downloaded&lt;br/&gt;
the 17 January 2003.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Detail:&lt;br/&gt;
=======&lt;br/&gt;
In org.apache.commons.lang.StringUtils: If you invoke&lt;br/&gt;
public static String replace(String text, String repl, String with)&lt;br/&gt;
with arguments:&lt;br/&gt;
   text  !=  null&lt;br/&gt;
   repl.equals(&quot;&quot;)&lt;br/&gt;
   with  anything&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;you get an infinite loop as &quot;FOO&quot;.indexOf(&quot;&quot;) == 0.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Demo:&lt;br/&gt;
=====&lt;br/&gt;
To demonstrate the bug, please add the following lines in&lt;br/&gt;
org.apache.commons.lang.StringUtilsTest in the body of&lt;br/&gt;
testReplaceFunctions(), line 194:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    public void testReplaceFunctions() &lt;/p&gt;
{

      //... existing code

      //-- bug demonstration, added by HoKr
      assertEquals(&quot;replace(String, String, String) failed&quot;,
          &quot;FOO&quot;, StringUtils.replace(&quot;FOO&quot;, &quot;&quot;, &quot;any&quot;));
    }

&lt;p&gt;I got an OutOfMemoryException then.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Fix:&lt;br/&gt;
====&lt;br/&gt;
My suggestion to fix this in StringUtils.replace(String, String, String),&lt;br/&gt;
line 593:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;    public static String replace(String text, String repl, String with,&lt;br/&gt;
                                 int max) {&lt;br/&gt;
        if (text == null) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            return null;
        }&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;br/&gt;
        //-- FIX SUGGESTION START &amp;gt;&amp;gt;&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
        //-- added by HoKr for infinite loop avoidance&lt;br/&gt;
        //-- keeps on throwing NullPointerException if repl == null&lt;br/&gt;
        //-- --&amp;gt;&amp;gt; this is faster than &quot;&quot;.equals(repl); NPE allowed.&lt;br/&gt;
        if (repl.length() == 0) {
           return text;
        }&lt;br/&gt;
        //-- &amp;lt;&amp;lt;&amp;lt; FIX SUGGESTION END&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;br/&gt;
        StringBuffer buf = new StringBuffer(text.length());&lt;br/&gt;
        int start = 0, end = 0;&lt;br/&gt;
        while ((end = text.indexOf(repl, start)) != -1) {&lt;br/&gt;
            buf.append(text.substring(start, end)).append(with);&lt;br/&gt;
            start = end + repl.length();&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;br/&gt;
            if (--max == 0) {
                break;
            }&lt;br/&gt;
        }&lt;br/&gt;
        buf.append(text.substring(start));&lt;br/&gt;
        return buf.toString();&lt;br/&gt;
    }&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;br/&gt;
Further:&lt;br/&gt;
========&lt;br/&gt;
Further I suggest instead of throwing NullPointerExceptions&lt;br/&gt;
if (repl == null || with == null) to return the parameter text then.&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;br/&gt;
It would meet closer the expectation of what the method should perform from&lt;br/&gt;
my point of view in these cases.&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;br/&gt;
This behaviour would be payed with 2 extra comparisons to null&lt;br/&gt;
(before the while-loop) in &apos;normal&apos; operation mode though.&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;br/&gt;
The Code would be:&lt;br/&gt;
&lt;br/&gt;
    public static String replace(String text, String repl, String with,&lt;br/&gt;
                                 int max) {&lt;br/&gt;
        if (text == null) {            return null;        }

&lt;p&gt;        //-- START &amp;gt;&amp;gt;&amp;gt;&lt;br/&gt;
        //-- suggestion by HoKr, BUT would CHANGE outside behaviour:&lt;br/&gt;
        //-- not throwing NPE any more!&lt;br/&gt;
        if (repl == null || with == null) &lt;/p&gt;
{
            return text;
        }&lt;br/&gt;
        //-- added by HoKr for infinite loop avoidance&lt;br/&gt;
        //-- keeps on throwing NullPointerException if repl == null&lt;br/&gt;
        if (repl.length() == 0) {            return text;        }
&lt;p&gt;        //-- &amp;lt;&amp;lt;&amp;lt; END&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;        StringBuffer buf = new StringBuffer(text.length());&lt;br/&gt;
        int start = 0, end = 0;&lt;br/&gt;
        while ((end = text.indexOf(repl, start)) != -1) {&lt;br/&gt;
            buf.append(text.substring(start, end)).append(with);&lt;br/&gt;
            start = end + repl.length();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;            if (--max == 0) &lt;/p&gt;
{
                break;
            }
&lt;p&gt;        }&lt;br/&gt;
        buf.append(text.substring(start));&lt;br/&gt;
        return buf.toString();&lt;br/&gt;
    }&lt;/p&gt;



&lt;p&gt;Regards,&lt;br/&gt;
Holger Krauth&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: Linux&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: PC&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12340493">LANG-15</key>
            <summary>Infinite loop in StringUtils.replace(text, repl, with) + FIX</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-14] [lang] Throwable cause for NotImplementedException</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-14</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The objective is to be able to signal a unsupported catch block :&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt; try &lt;/p&gt;
{
    ...
 }
&lt;p&gt; catch (... e) &lt;/p&gt;
{
    throw new NotImplentedException(&quot;... &amp;lt;case description&amp;gt; ...&quot;, e);
 }</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-13] [lang] DateUtils.truncate() is off by one hour when using a date in DST switch &apos;zone&apos;</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-13</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;Try this using a Central European TimeZone:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;import java.util.Calendar;&lt;br/&gt;
import org.apache.commons.lang.time.DateUtils;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Calendar cal = Calendar.getInstance();&lt;br/&gt;
cal.set(Calendar.MONTH, Calendar.MARCH);&lt;br/&gt;
cal.set(Calendar.YEAR, 2003);&lt;br/&gt;
cal.set(Calendar.DAY_OF_MONTH, 30);&lt;br/&gt;
cal.set(Calendar.HOUR_OF_DAY, 5);&lt;br/&gt;
cal.set(Calendar.MINUTE, 0);&lt;br/&gt;
cal.set(Calendar.SECOND, 0);&lt;br/&gt;
Date date_20030330 = cal.getTime();&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Date expDate = DateUtils.truncate(date_20030330, Calendar.DATE);&lt;br/&gt;
System.out.println(expDate.toString());&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;-&amp;gt; Sat Mar 29 23:00:00 MET 2003 instead of Sun Mar 30 00:00:00 MET 2003&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;If the calendar instance represents a date AFTER the daylight savings time&lt;br/&gt;
switch and will be truncated to a time BEFORE the daylight savings time switch,&lt;br/&gt;
then the resulting date is wrong. (Daylight savings time was Sun Mar 30 02:00:00&lt;br/&gt;
resetting to 01:00.00.) Might also happen when rounding up dates over the&lt;br/&gt;
daylight savings time switch...&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: All&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: All&lt;/p&gt;</environment>
        <key id="12341159">LANG-13</key>
            <summary>[lang] DateUtils.truncate() is off by one hour when using a date in DST switch &apos;zone&apos;</summary>
                <type id="1" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/viewavatar?size=xsmall&amp;avatarId=21133&amp;avatarType=issuetype">Bug</type>
                                            <priority id="3" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/priorities/major.svg">Major</priority>
                        <status id="6" iconUrl="https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/statuses/closed.png" description="The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.">Closed</status>
                    <statusCategory id="3" key="done" colorName="green"/>
                                    <resolution id="1">Fixed</resolution>
                                        <assignee username="-1">Unassigned</assignee>
                                    <reporter username="joachim.hagger@netcetera.ch">Joachim Hagger</reporter>
                        <labels>
                    </labels>
                <created>Tue, 16 Dec 2003 18:44:27 +0000</created>
                <updated>Wed, 16 Dec 2009 08:51:53 +0000</updated>
                            <resolved>Wed, 16 Dec 2009 08:51:53 +0000</resolved>
                                    <version>2.0</version>
                                    <fixVersion>2.1</fixVersion>
                                    <component>lang.time.*</component>
                        <due></due>
                            <votes>0</votes>
                                    <watches>0</watches>
                                                                <comments>
                            <comment id="12405662" author="stevencaswell@apache.org" created="Mon, 5 Jul 2004 04:20:09 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The appears to be fixable with a minor change to the DateUtils.modify method,&lt;br/&gt;
replacing the val.add call with a val.set call, doing the calculation external&lt;br/&gt;
to the Calendar instance. For some reason, the Calendar.add method subtracts an&lt;br/&gt;
additional hour in the particular test scenario mentioned in the bug report, but&lt;br/&gt;
doesn&apos;t with other timezones I tested (such as US/Eastern). So I think the&lt;br/&gt;
easiest fix is to do the calculation in our code.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;I have changed the DateUtils.modify method and the existing tests pass. I&apos;ve&lt;br/&gt;
written one test to verify the fix works with the above scenario, and I plan to&lt;br/&gt;
write some additional tests for rounding.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405663" author="stevencaswell@apache.org" created="Mon, 5 Jul 2004 04:34:05 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;After some more testing, the light bulb came on as to why the Calendar.add&lt;br/&gt;
method seemed to be overshooting the correct date and subtracting 6 hours&lt;br/&gt;
instead of five. This is probably a &quot;duh&quot; for most everyone else, but it took me&lt;br/&gt;
a few minutes to see it. The DateUtils.modify method, which does the gruntwork&lt;br/&gt;
of the round and truncate methods, was subtracting the number of hours from the&lt;br/&gt;
date being rounded/truncated. In this paricular case, it was subtracting 5 hours&lt;br/&gt;
to get from 05:00 to 00:00. However, since the scenario happened to cause this&lt;br/&gt;
across a DST enablement, Calendar.add was treating the time between 02:00 and&lt;br/&gt;
03:00 as non-existing, so subtracting 5 hours from 05:00 was giving 23:00 on the&lt;br/&gt;
previous day, which is technically correct. But for a rounding/truncation&lt;br/&gt;
method, this is not appropriate, so my earlier solution of calculating the&lt;br/&gt;
desired hour value and using set does appear to be appropriate.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Note that I did a few tests on rounding across the 02:00/03:00 barrier, and the&lt;br/&gt;
rounding also &quot;ignores&quot; the missing hour. So for example, rounding 01:40 gives&lt;br/&gt;
03:00, and rounding 02:40 give 04:00, which IMHO are both correct, since the&lt;br/&gt;
02:00-03:00 hour does not exist.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405664" author="stevencaswell@apache.org" created="Mon, 12 Jul 2004 00:04:48 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;The truncate/round logic was adding a negative value to the current hours (using&lt;br/&gt;
Calendar.add) to move the hours back to zero. When this is done across the&lt;br/&gt;
beginning of daylight saving time, it has the affect of moving to 23:00 of the&lt;br/&gt;
previous day, because the hour skipped when daylight saving time doesn&apos;t exist.&lt;br/&gt;
For example, if daylight saving time begins at 02:00, and -5 is added to 05:00,&lt;br/&gt;
the result is 23:00 of yesterday, because the hour between 02:00 and 03:00&lt;br/&gt;
doesn&apos;t exist. The fix was to do the calculation in the truncate/round code, and&lt;br/&gt;
use Calendar.set to set the new hour value.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405665" author="apa3a@yahoo.com" created="Mon, 4 Apr 2005 04:20:12 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;Just hit this bug using 2.0.&lt;br/&gt;
This is what happens to those who work on Sundays &lt;img class=&quot;emoticon&quot; src=&quot;https://issues.apache.org/jira/images/icons/emoticons/smile.png&quot; height=&quot;16&quot; width=&quot;16&quot; align=&quot;absmiddle&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;/&gt;.&lt;br/&gt;
Very delighted that fix exists. I&apos;m about to give my app to the client and don&apos;t&lt;br/&gt;
want to use current CVS or custom-patched library. Found a workaround:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;DateUtils.truncate(date, Calendar.DATE)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;use:&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;DateUtils.round(&lt;br/&gt;
        DateUtils.truncate(date, Calendar.DATE),&lt;br/&gt;
        Calendar.DATE)&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Call to round eliminates any 1-hour discrepancy which may exist.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                            <comment id="12405666" author="bayard" created="Wed, 26 Apr 2006 13:10:57 +0000"  >&lt;p&gt;2.1 released, closing.&lt;/p&gt;</comment>
                    </comments>
                    <attachments>
                    </attachments>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-12] Example in Javadoc for ToStringBuilder wrong for append.</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-12</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;The following is directly from the Javadoc page. Please see inline notes.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;
	&lt;ul&gt;
		&lt;li&gt;
		&lt;ul&gt;
			&lt;li&gt;Begin Quote ***&lt;br/&gt;
To use this class write code as follows: &lt;/li&gt;
		&lt;/ul&gt;
		&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;/ul&gt;
	&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt; public class Person {&lt;br/&gt;
   String name;&lt;br/&gt;
   int age;&lt;br/&gt;
   boolean isSmoker;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;   ...&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;   public String toString() &lt;/p&gt;
{
     return new ToStringBuilder(this).
       append(name, &quot;name&quot;).     //!! should be - append(&quot;name&quot;, name).
       append(age, &quot;age&quot;).       //!! should be - append(&quot;age&quot;, age).
       append(smoker, &quot;smoker&quot;). //!! should be - append(&quot;smoker&quot;, smoker).
       toString();
   }
&lt;p&gt; }&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;ul&gt;
	&lt;li&gt;
	&lt;ul&gt;
		&lt;li&gt;
		&lt;ul&gt;
			&lt;li&gt;End Quote ***&lt;/li&gt;
		&lt;/ul&gt;
		&lt;/li&gt;
	&lt;/ul&gt;
	&lt;/li&gt;
&lt;/ul&gt;


&lt;p&gt;In short, the order of arguments to the append method in the example have been &lt;br/&gt;
reversed.&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p&gt;Thank you.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
                <environment>&lt;p&gt;Operating System: other&lt;br/&gt;
Platform: Other&lt;/p&gt;</environment>

<item>
            <title>[LANG-10] [lang] [patch] ClassUtils.primitiveToWrapper and Void</title>
                <link>https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LANG-10</link>
                <project id="12310481" key="LANG">Commons Lang</project>
                    <description>&lt;p&gt;ClassUtils.primitiveToWrapper returns null when the specified Class is&lt;br/&gt;
Void.TYPE. Because Void.TYPE is primitive but not present into&lt;br/&gt;
primitiveWrapperMap. Should return Void.TYPE instead.&lt;/p&gt;</description>
